And the very idea of\r\nhaving you to care for under my roof would force me to moderate my\r\nexpenses and live like a Christian\xe2\x80\x94not to speak of all the prudence and\r\nvirtue you would instil into my mind by your wise counsels and sweet,\r\nattractive goodness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is not that,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; \xe2\x80\x9cit is not money my aunt thinks about.\r\nShe knows better than to value worldly wealth above its price.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe wishes me to\xe2\x80\x94to marry none but a really good man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, a man of \xe2\x80\x98decided piety\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x94ahem!\xe2\x80\x94Well, come, I\xe2\x80\x99ll manage that\r\ntoo! It\xe2\x80\x99s Sunday to-day, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to church morning,\r\nafternoon, and evening, and comport myself in such a godly sort that\r\nshe shall regard me with admiration and sisterly love, as a brand\r\nplucked from the burning. I\xe2\x80\x99ll come home sighing like a furnace, and\r\nfull of the savour and unction of dear Mr. Blatant\xe2\x80\x99s discourse\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Leighton,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, dryly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Leighton a \xe2\x80\x98sweet preacher,\xe2\x80\x99 Helen\xe2\x80\x94a \xe2\x80\x98dear, delightful,\r\nheavenly-minded man\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a _good_ man, Mr. Huntingdon. I wish I could say half as much\r\nfor you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I forgot, you are a saint, too. I crave your pardon, dearest\xe2\x80\x94but\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t call me Mr. Huntingdon; my name is Arthur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll call you nothing\xe2\x80\x94for I\xe2\x80\x99ll have nothing at all to do with you if\r\nyou talk in that way any more. If you really mean to deceive my aunt as\r\nyou say, you are very wicked; and if not, you are very wrong to jest on\r\nsuch a subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI stand corrected,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, concluding his laugh with a sorrowful\r\nsigh. \xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed he, after a momentary pause, \xe2\x80\x9clet us talk about\r\nsomething else. And come nearer to me, Helen, and take my arm; and then\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll let you alone. I can\xe2\x80\x99t be quiet while I see you walking there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI complied; but said we must soon return to the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one will be down to breakfast yet, for long enough,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou spoke of your guardians just now, Helen, but is not your father\r\nstill living?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but I always look upon my uncle and aunt as my guardians, for\r\nthey are so in deed, though not in name. My father has entirely given\r\nme up to their care. I have never seen him since dear mamma died, when\r\nI was a very little girl, and my aunt, at her request, offered to take\r\ncharge of me, and took me away to Staningley, where I have remained\r\never since; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he would object to anything for me that\r\nshe thought proper to sanction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut would he sanction anything to which she thought proper to object?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think he cares enough about me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very much to blame\xe2\x80\x94but he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know what an angel he has for\r\nhis daughter\xe2\x80\x94which is all the better for me, as, if he did, he would\r\nnot be willing to part with such a treasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Mr. Huntingdon,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you _know_ I am not an\r\nheiress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe protested he had never given it a thought, and begged I would not\r\ndisturb his present enjoyment by the mention of such uninteresting\r\nsubjects. I was glad of this proof of disinterested affection; for\r\nAnnabella Wilmot is the probable heiress to all her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s wealth, in\r\naddition to her late father\xe2\x80\x99s property, which she has already in\r\npossession.\r\n\r\nI now insisted upon retracing our steps to the house; but we walked\r\nslowly, and went on talking as we proceeded. I need not repeat all we\r\nsaid: let me rather refer to what passed between my aunt and me, after\r\nbreakfast, when Mr. Huntingdon called my uncle aside, no doubt to make\r\nhis proposals, and she beckoned me into another room, where she once\r\nmore commenced a solemn remonstrance, which, however, entirely failed\r\nto convince me that her view of the case was preferable to my own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou judge him uncharitably, aunt, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cHis very friends\r\nare not half so bad as you represent them. There is Walter Hargrave,\r\nMilicent\xe2\x80\x99s brother, for one: he is but a little lower than the angels,\r\nif half she says of him is true. She is continually talking to me about\r\nhim, and lauding his many virtues to the skies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will form a very inadequate estimate of a man\xe2\x80\x99s character,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied she, \xe2\x80\x9cif you judge by what a fond sister says of him. The worst\r\nof them generally know how to hide their misdeeds from their sisters\xe2\x80\x99\r\neyes, and their mother\xe2\x80\x99s, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there is Lord Lowborough,\xe2\x80\x9d continued I, \xe2\x80\x9cquite a decent man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you so? Lord Lowborough is a _desperate_ man. He has\r\ndissipated his fortune in gambling and other things, and is now seeking\r\nan heiress to retrieve it. I told Miss Wilmot so; but you\xe2\x80\x99re all alike:\r\nshe haughtily answered she was very much obliged to me, but she\r\nbelieved _she_ knew when a man was seeking her for her fortune, and\r\nwhen for herself; she flattered herself she had had experience enough\r\nin those matters to be justified in trusting to her own judgment\xe2\x80\x94and as\r\nfor his lordship\xe2\x80\x99s lack of fortune, she cared nothing about that, as\r\nshe hoped her own would suffice for both; and as for his wildness, she\r\nsupposed he was no worse than others\xe2\x80\x94besides, he was reformed now. Yes,\r\nthey can all play the hypocrite when they want to take in a fond,\r\nmisguided woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I think he\xe2\x80\x99s about as good as she is,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cBut when Mr.\r\nHuntingdon is married, he won\xe2\x80\x99t have many opportunities of consorting\r\nwith his bachelor friends;\xe2\x80\x94and the worse they are, the more I long to\r\ndeliver him from them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, my dear; and the worse _he_ is, I suppose, the more you\r\nlong to deliver him from himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, provided he is not incorrigible\xe2\x80\x94that is, the more I long to\r\ndeliver him from his faults\xe2\x80\x94to give him an opportunity of shaking off\r\nthe adventitious evil got from contact with others worse than himself,\r\nand shining out in the unclouded light of his own genuine goodness\xe2\x80\x94to\r\ndo my utmost to help his better self against his worse, and make him\r\nwhat he would have been if he had not, from the beginning, had a bad,\r\nselfish, miserly father, who, to gratify his own sordid passions,\r\nrestricted him in the most innocent enjoyments of childhood and youth,\r\nand so disgusted him with every kind of restraint;\xe2\x80\x94and a foolish mother\r\nwho indulged him to the top of his bent, deceiving her husband for him,\r\nand doing her utmost to encourage those germs of folly and vice it was\r\nher duty to suppress,\xe2\x80\x94and then, such a set of companions as you\r\nrepresent his friends to be\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor man!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, sarcastically, \xe2\x80\x9chis kind have greatly wronged\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have!\xe2\x80\x9d cried I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand they shall wrong him no more\xe2\x80\x94his wife shall\r\nundo what his mother did!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, after a short pause, \xe2\x80\x9cI must say, Helen, I thought\r\nbetter of your judgment than this\xe2\x80\x94and your taste too. How you can love\r\nsuch a man I cannot tell, or what pleasure you can find in his company;\r\nfor \xe2\x80\x98what fellowship hath light with darkness; or he that believeth\r\nwith an infidel?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not an infidel;\xe2\x80\x94and I am not light, and he is not darkness; his\r\nworst and only vice is thoughtlessness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thoughtlessness,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued my aunt, \xe2\x80\x9cmay lead to every crime, and\r\nwill but poorly excuse our errors in the sight of God. Mr. Huntingdon,\r\nI suppose, is not without the common faculties of men: he is not so\r\nlight-headed as to be irresponsible: his Maker has endowed him with\r\nreason and conscience as well as the rest of us; the Scriptures are\r\nopen to him as well as to others;\xe2\x80\x94and \xe2\x80\x98if he hear not them, neither\r\nwill he hear though one rose from the dead.\xe2\x80\x99 And remember, Helen,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued she, solemnly, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98the wicked shall be turned into hell, and\r\nthey that _forget_ God!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d And suppose, even, that he should continue to\r\nlove you, and you him, and that you should pass through life together\r\nwith tolerable comfort\xe2\x80\x94how will it be in the end, when you see\r\nyourselves parted for ever; you, perhaps, taken into eternal bliss, and\r\nhe cast into the lake that burneth with unquenchable fire\xe2\x80\x94there for\r\never to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for ever,\xe2\x80\x9d I exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98only till he has paid the uttermost\r\nfarthing;\xe2\x80\x99 for \xe2\x80\x98if any man\xe2\x80\x99s work abide not the fire, he shall suffer\r\nloss, yet himself shall be saved, but so as by fire;\xe2\x80\x99 and He that \xe2\x80\x98is\r\nable to subdue all things to Himself will have all men to be saved,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand \xe2\x80\x98will, in the fulness of time, gather together in one all things in\r\nChrist Jesus, who tasted death for every man, and in whom God will\r\nreconcile all things to Himself, whether they be things in earth or\r\nthings in heaven.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Helen! where did you learn all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the Bible, aunt. I have searched it through, and found nearly\r\nthirty passages, all tending to support the same theory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is _that_ the use you make of your Bible? And did you find no\r\npassages tending to prove the danger and the falsity of such a belief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo: I found, indeed, some passages that, taken by themselves, might\r\nseem to contradict that opinion; but they will all bear a different\r\nconstruction to that which is commonly given, and in most the only\r\ndifficulty is in the word which we translate \xe2\x80\x98everlasting\xe2\x80\x99 or\r\n\xe2\x80\x98eternal.\xe2\x80\x99 I don\xe2\x80\x99t know the Greek, but I believe it strictly means for\r\nages, and might signify either endless or long-enduring. And as for the\r\ndanger of the belief, I would not publish it abroad if I thought any\r\npoor wretch would be likely to presume upon it to his own destruction,\r\nbut it is a glorious thought to cherish in one\xe2\x80\x99s own heart, and I would\r\nnot part with it for all the world can give!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere our conference ended, for it was now high time to prepare for\r\nchurch. Every one attended the morning service, except my uncle, who\r\nhardly ever goes, and Mr. Wilmot, who stayed at home with him to enjoy\r\na quiet game of cribbage. In the afternoon Miss Wilmot and Lord\r\nLowborough likewise excused themselves from attending; but Mr.\r\nHuntingdon vouchsafed to accompany us again. Whether it was to\r\ningratiate himself with my aunt I cannot tell, but, if so, he certainly\r\nshould have behaved better. I must confess, I did not like his conduct\r\nduring service at all. Holding his prayer-book upside down, or open at\r\nany place but the right, he did nothing but stare about him, unless he\r\nhappened to catch my aunt\xe2\x80\x99s eye or mine, and then he would drop his own\r\non his book, with a puritanical air of mock solemnity that would have\r\nbeen ludicrous, if it had not been too provoking. Once, during the\r\nsermon, after attentively regarding Mr. Leighton for a few minutes, he\r\nsuddenly produced his gold pencil-case and snatched up a Bible.\r\nPerceiving that I observed the movement, he whispered that he was going\r\nto make a note of the sermon; but instead of that, as I sat next him, I\r\ncould not help seeing that he was making a caricature of the preacher,\r\ngiving to the respectable, pious, elderly gentleman, the air and aspect\r\nof a most absurd old hypocrite. And yet, upon his return, he talked to\r\nmy aunt about the sermon with a degree of modest, serious\r\ndiscrimination that tempted me to believe he had really attended to and\r\nprofited by the discourse.\r\n\r\nJust before dinner my uncle called me into the library for the\r\ndiscussion of a very important matter, which was dismissed in few\r\nwords.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Nell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthis young Huntingdon has been asking for you:\r\nwhat must I say about it? Your aunt would answer \xe2\x80\x98no\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94but what say\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say yes, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d replied I, without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation; for I had\r\nthoroughly made up my mind on the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cNow that\xe2\x80\x99s a good honest answer\xe2\x80\x94wonderful for a\r\ngirl!\xe2\x80\x94Well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll write to your father to-morrow. He\xe2\x80\x99s sure to give his\r\nconsent; so you may look on the matter as settled. You\xe2\x80\x99d have done a\r\ndeal better if you\xe2\x80\x99d taken Wilmot, I can tell you; but that you won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbelieve. At your time of life, it\xe2\x80\x99s love that rules the roast: at mine,\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s solid, serviceable gold. I suppose now, you\xe2\x80\x99d never dream of\r\nlooking into the state of your husband\xe2\x80\x99s finances, or troubling your\r\nhead about settlements, or anything of that sort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think I should.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, be thankful, then, that you\xe2\x80\x99ve wiser heads to think for you. I\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t had time, yet, to examine thoroughly into this young rascal\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naffairs, but I see that a great part of his father\xe2\x80\x99s fine property has\r\nbeen squandered away;\xe2\x80\x94but still, I think, there\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty fair share\r\nof it left, and a little careful nursing may make a handsome thing of\r\nit yet; and then we must persuade your father to give you a decent\r\nfortune, as he has only one besides yourself to care for;\xe2\x80\x94and, if you\r\nbehave well, who knows but what I may be induced to remember you in my\r\nwill!\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, putting his fingers to his nose, with a knowing\r\nwink.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, uncle, for that and all your kindness,\xe2\x80\x9d replied I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and I questioned this young spark on the matter of settlements,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued he; \xe2\x80\x9cand he seemed disposed to be generous enough on that\r\npoint\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew he would!\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cBut pray don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble your head\xe2\x80\x94or his, or\r\nmine about that; for all I have will be his, and all he has will be\r\nmine; and what more could either of us require?\xe2\x80\x9d And I was about to\r\nmake my exit, but he called me back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop, stop!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; \xe2\x80\x9cwe haven\xe2\x80\x99t mentioned the time yet. When must\r\nit be? Your aunt would put it off till the Lord knows when, but he is\r\nanxious to be bound as soon as may be: he won\xe2\x80\x99t hear of waiting beyond\r\nnext month; and you, I guess, will be of the same mind, so\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all, uncle; on the contrary, I should like to wait till after\r\nChristmas, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! pooh, pooh! never tell me that tale\xe2\x80\x94I know better,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; and\r\nhe persisted in his incredulity. Nevertheless, it is quite true. I am\r\nin no hurry at all. How can I be, when I think of the momentous change\r\nthat awaits me, and of all I have to leave? It is happiness enough to\r\nknow that we _are_ to be united; and that he really loves me, and I may\r\nlove _him_ as devotedly, and think of him as often as I please.\r\nHowever, I insisted upon consulting my aunt about the _time_ of the\r\nwedding, for I determined her counsels should not be utterly\r\ndisregarded; and no conclusions on that particular are come to yet.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXI\r\n\r\n\r\nOctober 1st.\xe2\x80\x94All is settled now. My father has given his consent, and\r\nthe time is fixed for Christmas, by a sort of compromise between the\r\nrespective advocates for hurry and delay. Milicent Hargrave is to be\r\none bridesmaid and Annabella Wilmot the other\xe2\x80\x94not that I am\r\nparticularly fond of the latter, but she is an intimate of the family,\r\nand I have not another friend.\r\n\r\nWhen I told Milicent of my engagement, she rather provoked me by her\r\nmanner of taking it. After staring a moment in mute surprise, she\r\nsaid,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Helen, I suppose I ought to congratulate you\xe2\x80\x94and I _am_ glad to\r\nsee you so happy; but I did not think you would take him; and I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhelp feeling surprised that you should like him so much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you are so superior to him in every way, and there\xe2\x80\x99s something\r\nso bold and reckless about him\xe2\x80\x94so, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how\xe2\x80\x94but I always feel a\r\nwish to get out of his way when I see him approach.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are timid, Milicent; but that\xe2\x80\x99s no fault of his.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then his look,\xe2\x80\x9d continued she. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople say he\xe2\x80\x99s handsome, and of\r\ncourse he is; but _I_ don\xe2\x80\x99t _like_ that kind of beauty, and I wonder\r\nthat you should.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so, pray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know, I think there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing noble or lofty in his\r\nappearance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn fact, you wonder that I can like any one so unlike the stilted\r\nheroes of romance. Well, give me my flesh and blood lover, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nleave all the Sir Herberts and Valentines to you\xe2\x80\x94if you can find them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want them,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be satisfied with flesh and blood\r\ntoo\xe2\x80\x94only the spirit must shine through and predominate. But don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nthink Mr. Huntingdon\xe2\x80\x99s face is too red?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, indignantly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not red at all. There is just a\r\npleasant glow, a healthy freshness in his complexion\xe2\x80\x94the warm, pinky\r\ntint of the whole harmonising with the deeper colour of the cheeks,\r\nexactly as it ought to do. I hate a man to be red and white, like a\r\npainted doll, or all sickly white, or smoky black, or cadaverous\r\nyellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, tastes differ\xe2\x80\x94but _I_ like pale or dark,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, to\r\ntell you the truth, Helen, I had been deluding myself with the hope\r\nthat you would one day be my sister. I expected Walter would be\r\nintroduced to you next season; and I thought you would like him, and\r\nwas certain he would like you; and I flattered myself I should thus\r\nhave the felicity of seeing the two persons I like best in the\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x94except mamma\xe2\x80\x94united in one. He mayn\xe2\x80\x99t be exactly what you would\r\ncall handsome, but he\xe2\x80\x99s far more distinguished-looking, and nicer and\r\nbetter than Mr. Huntingdon;\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you would say so, if you knew\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible, Milicent! You think so, because you\xe2\x80\x99re his sister; and, on\r\nthat account, I\xe2\x80\x99ll forgive you; but nobody else should so disparage\r\nArthur Huntingdon to me with impunity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Wilmot expressed her feelings on the subject almost as openly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, Helen,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, coming up to me with a smile of no amiable\r\nimport, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are to be Mrs. Huntingdon, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied I. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you envy me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, _dear_, no!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall probably be Lady Lowborough\r\nsome day, and then you know, dear, I shall be in a capacity to inquire,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you envy _me?_\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHenceforth I shall envy no one,\xe2\x80\x9d returned I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! Are you so happy then?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, thoughtfully; and something\r\nvery like a cloud of disappointment shadowed her face. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd does he\r\nlove you\xe2\x80\x94I mean, does he idolise you as much as you do him?\xe2\x80\x9d she added,\r\nfixing her eyes upon me with ill-disguised anxiety for the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be idolised,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I am well assured that\r\nhe _loves_ me more than anybody else in the world\xe2\x80\x94as I do him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, with a nod. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d she paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you wish?\xe2\x80\x9d asked I, annoyed at the vindictive expression of\r\nher countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish,\xe2\x80\x9d returned, she, with a short laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cthat all the attractive\r\npoints and desirable qualifications of the two gentlemen were united in\r\none\xe2\x80\x94that Lord Lowborough had Huntingdon\xe2\x80\x99s handsome face and good\r\ntemper, and all his wit, and mirth and charm, or else that Huntingdon\r\nhad Lowborough\xe2\x80\x99s pedigree, and title, and delightful old family seat,\r\nand I had him; and you might have the other and welcome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, dear Annabella: I am better satisfied with things as they\r\nare, for my own part; and for you, I wish you were as well content with\r\nyour intended as I am with mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; and it was true enough; for,\r\nthough vexed at first at her unamiable spirit, her frankness touched\r\nme, and the contrast between our situations was such, that I could well\r\nafford to pity her and wish her well.\r\n\r\nMr. Huntingdon\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintances appear to be no better pleased with our\r\napproaching union than mine. This morning\xe2\x80\x99s post brought him letters\r\nfrom several of his friends, during the perusal of which, at the\r\nbreakfast-table, he excited the attention of the company by the\r\nsingular variety of his grimaces. But he crushed them all into his\r\npocket, with a private laugh, and said nothing till the meal was\r\nconcluded. Then, while the company were hanging over the fire or\r\nloitering through the room, previous to settling to their various\r\nmorning avocations, he came and leant over the back of my chair, with\r\nhis face in contact with my curls, and commencing with a quiet little\r\nkiss, poured forth the following complaints into my ear:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen, you witch, do you know that you\xe2\x80\x99ve entailed upon me the curses\r\nof all my friends? I wrote to them the other day, to tell them of my\r\nhappy prospects, and now, instead of a bundle of congratulations, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ngot a pocketful of bitter execrations and reproaches. There\xe2\x80\x99s not one\r\nkind wish for me, or one good word for you, among them all. They say\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99ll be no more fun now, no more merry days and glorious nights\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nall my fault\xe2\x80\x94I am the first to break up the jovial band, and others, in\r\npure despair, will follow my example. I was the very life and prop of\r\nthe community, they do me the honour to say, and I have shamefully\r\nbetrayed my trust\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may join them again, if you like,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, somewhat piqued at the\r\nsorrowful tone of his discourse. \xe2\x80\x9cI should be sorry to stand between\r\nany man\xe2\x80\x94or body of men, and so much happiness; and perhaps I can manage\r\nto do without you, as well as your poor deserted friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless you, no,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98all for love or the world well\r\nlost,\xe2\x80\x99 with me. Let them go to\xe2\x80\x94where they belong, to speak politely.\r\nBut if you saw how they abuse me, Helen, you would love me all the more\r\nfor having ventured so much for your sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pulled out his crumpled letters. I thought he was going to show them\r\nto me, and told him I did not wish to see them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going to show them to you, love,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re hardly fit\r\nfor a lady\xe2\x80\x99s eyes\xe2\x80\x94the most part of them. But look here. This is\r\nGrimsby\xe2\x80\x99s scrawl\xe2\x80\x94only three lines, the sulky dog! He doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say much,\r\nto be sure, but his very silence implies more than all the others\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwords, and the less he says, the more he thinks\xe2\x80\x94and this is Hargrave\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmissive. He is particularly grieved at me, because, forsooth he had\r\nfallen in love with you from his sister\xe2\x80\x99s reports, and meant to have\r\nmarried you himself, as soon as he had sown his wild oats.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m vastly obliged to him,\xe2\x80\x9d observed I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so am I,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd look at this. This is Hattersley\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94every\r\npage stuffed full of railing accusations, bitter curses, and lamentable\r\ncomplaints, ending up with swearing that he\xe2\x80\x99ll get married himself in\r\nrevenge: he\xe2\x80\x99ll throw himself away on the first old maid that chooses to\r\nset her cap at him,\xe2\x80\x94as if _I_ cared what he did with himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cif you do give up your intimacy with these men, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t think you will have much cause to regret the loss of their\r\nsociety; for it\xe2\x80\x99s my belief they never did you much good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe not; but we\xe2\x80\x99d a merry time of it, too, though mingled with\r\nsorrow and pain, as Lowborough knows to his cost\xe2\x80\x94Ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d and while he\r\nwas laughing at the recollection of Lowborough\xe2\x80\x99s troubles, my uncle\r\ncame and slapped him on the shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, my lad!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you too busy making love to my niece to\r\nmake war with the pheasants?\xe2\x80\x94First of October, remember! Sun shines\r\nout\xe2\x80\x94rain ceased\xe2\x80\x94even Boarham\xe2\x80\x99s not afraid to venture in his waterproof\r\nboots; and Wilmot and I are going to beat you all. I declare, we old\r\n\xe2\x80\x99uns are the keenest sportsmen of the lot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show you what I can do to-day, however,\xe2\x80\x9d said my companion. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nmurder your birds by wholesale, just for keeping me away from better\r\ncompany than either you or them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so saying he departed; and I saw no more of him till dinner. It\r\nseemed a weary time; I wonder what I shall do without him.\r\n\r\nIt is very true that the three elder gentlemen have proved themselves\r\nmuch keener sportsmen than the two younger ones; for both Lord\r\nLowborough and Arthur Huntingdon have of late almost daily neglected\r\nthe shooting excursions to accompany us in our various rides and\r\nrambles. But these merry times are fast drawing to a close. In less\r\nthan a fortnight the party break up, much to my sorrow, for every day I\r\nenjoy it more and more\xe2\x80\x94now that Messrs. Boarham and Wilmot have ceased\r\nto tease me, and my aunt has ceased to lecture me, and I have ceased to\r\nbe jealous of Annabella\xe2\x80\x94and even to dislike her\xe2\x80\x94and now that Mr.\r\nHuntingdon is become _my_ Arthur, and I may enjoy his society without\r\nrestraint. What _shall_ I do without him, I repeat?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXII\r\n\r\n\r\nOctober 5th.\xe2\x80\x94My cup of sweets is not unmingled: it is dashed with a\r\nbitterness that I cannot hide from myself, disguise it as I will. I may\r\ntry to persuade myself that the sweetness overpowers it; I may call it\r\na pleasant aromatic flavour; but say what I will, it is still there,\r\nand I cannot but taste it. I cannot shut my eyes to Arthur\xe2\x80\x99s faults;\r\nand the more I love him the more they trouble me. His very heart, that\r\nI trusted so, is, I fear, less warm and generous than I thought it. At\r\nleast, he gave me a specimen of his character to-day that seemed to\r\nmerit a harder name than thoughtlessness. He and Lord Lowborough were\r\naccompanying Annabella and me in a long, delightful ride; he was riding\r\nby my side, as usual, and Annabella and Lord Lowborough were a little\r\nbefore us, the latter bending towards his companion as if in tender and\r\nconfidential discourse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose two will get the start of us, Helen, if we don\xe2\x80\x99t look sharp,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nobserved Huntingdon. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll make a match of it, as sure as can be.\r\nThat Lowborough\xe2\x80\x99s fairly besotted. But he\xe2\x80\x99ll find himself in a fix when\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s got her, I doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she\xe2\x80\x99ll find _her_self in a fix when she\xe2\x80\x99s got _him_,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nwhat I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of him is true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit of it. She knows what she\xe2\x80\x99s about; but he, poor fool,\r\ndeludes himself with the notion that she\xe2\x80\x99ll make him a good wife, and\r\nbecause she has amused him with some rodomontade about despising rank\r\nand wealth in matters of love and marriage, he flatters himself that\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s devotedly attached to him; that she will not refuse him for his\r\npoverty, and does not court him for his rank, but loves him for himself\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut is not _he_ courting _her_ for her fortune?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not he. That was the first attraction, certainly; but now he has\r\nquite lost sight of it: it never enters his calculations, except merely\r\nas an essential without which, for the lady\xe2\x80\x99s own sake, he could not\r\nthink of marrying her. No; he\xe2\x80\x99s fairly in love. He thought he never\r\ncould be again, but he\xe2\x80\x99s in for it once more. He was to have been\r\nmarried before, some two or three years ago; but he lost his bride by\r\nlosing his fortune. He got into a bad way among us in London: he had an\r\nunfortunate taste for gambling; and surely the fellow was born under an\r\nunlucky star, for he always lost thrice where he gained once. That\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nmode of self-torment I never was much addicted to. When I spend my\r\nmoney I like to enjoy the full value of it: I see no fun in wasting it\r\non thieves and blacklegs; and as for _gaining_ money, hitherto I have\r\nalways had sufficient; it\xe2\x80\x99s time enough to be clutching for more, I\r\nthink, when you begin to see the end of what you have. But I have\r\nsometimes frequented the gaming-houses just to watch the on-goings of\r\nthose mad votaries of chance\xe2\x80\x94a very interesting study, I assure you,\r\nHelen, and sometimes very diverting: I\xe2\x80\x99ve had many a laugh at the\r\nboobies and bedlamites. Lowborough was quite infatuated\xe2\x80\x94not willingly,\r\nbut of necessity,\xe2\x80\x94he was always resolving to give it up, and always\r\nbreaking his resolutions. Every venture was the \xe2\x80\x9cjust once more:\xe2\x80\x9d if he\r\ngained a little, he hoped to gain a little more next time, and if he\r\nlost, it would not do to leave off at that juncture; he must go on till\r\nhe had retrieved that last misfortune, at least: bad luck could not\r\nlast for ever; and every lucky hit was looked upon as the dawn of\r\nbetter times, till experience proved the contrary. At length he grew\r\ndesperate, and we were daily on the look-out for a case of\r\n_felo-de-se_\xe2\x80\x94no great matter, some of us whispered, as his existence\r\nhad ceased to be an acquisition to our club. At last, however, he came\r\nto a check. He made a large stake, which he determined should be the\r\nlast, whether he lost or won. He had often so determined before, to be\r\nsure, and as often broken his determination; and so it was this time.\r\nHe lost; and while his antagonist smilingly swept away the stakes, he\r\nturned chalky white, drew back in silence, and wiped his forehead. I\r\nwas present at the time; and while he stood with folded arms and eyes\r\nfixed on the ground, I knew well enough what was passing in his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Is it to be the last, Lowborough?\xe2\x80\x99 said I, stepping up to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The last but ONE,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered, with a grim smile; and then, rushing\r\nback to the table, he struck his hand upon it, and, raising his voice\r\nhigh above all the confusion of jingling coins and muttered oaths and\r\ncurses in the room, he swore a deep and solemn oath that, come what\r\nwould, THIS trial _should_ be the last, and imprecated unspeakable\r\ncurses on his head if ever he should shuffle a card or rattle a\r\ndice-box again. He then doubled his former stake, and challenged any\r\none present to play against him. Grimsby instantly presented himself.\r\nLowborough glared fiercely at him, for Grimsby was almost as celebrated\r\nfor his luck as _he_ was for his ill-fortune. However, they fell to\r\nwork. But Grimsby had much skill and little scruple, and whether he\r\ntook advantage of the other\xe2\x80\x99s trembling, blinded eagerness to deal\r\nunfairly by him, I cannot undertake to say; but Lowborough lost again,\r\nand fell dead sick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99d better try once more,\xe2\x80\x99 said Grimsby, leaning across the table.\r\nAnd then he winked at me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing to try with,\xe2\x80\x99 said the poor devil, with a ghastly smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Huntingdon will lend you what you want,\xe2\x80\x99 said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No; you heard my oath,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Lowborough, turning away in quiet\r\ndespair. And I took him by the arm and led him out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Is it to be the last, Lowborough?\xe2\x80\x99 I asked, when I got him into the\r\nstreet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The last,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered, somewhat against my expectation. Many a better man than you has lived and died in\r\ndebt; and they can\xe2\x80\x99t put you in prison, you know, because you\xe2\x80\x99re a\r\npeer.\xe2\x80\x99 And I handed him his fourth tumbler.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98But I hate to be in debt!\xe2\x80\x99 he shouted. \xe2\x80\x98I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t born for it, and I\r\ncannot _bear_ it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What can\xe2\x80\x99t be cured must be endured,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, beginning to mix the\r\nfifth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And then, I\xe2\x80\x99ve lost my Caroline.\xe2\x80\x99 And he began to snivel then, for\r\nthe brandy had softened his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No matter,\xe2\x80\x99 I answered, \xe2\x80\x98there are more Carolines in the world than\r\none.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s only one for me,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied, with a dolorous sigh. \xe2\x80\x98And if\r\nthere were fifty more, who\xe2\x80\x99s to get them, I wonder, without money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Oh, somebody will take you for your title; and then you\xe2\x80\x99ve your\r\nfamily estate yet; that\xe2\x80\x99s entailed, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I wish to God I could sell it to pay my debts,\xe2\x80\x99 he muttered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Grimsby, who had just come in, \xe2\x80\x98you can _try again_,\r\nyou know. The\r\nconsequence of this imprudence was something like an apoplectic fit,\r\nfollowed by a rather severe brain fever\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did you think of _yourself_, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said I, quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, I was very penitent,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. \xe2\x80\x9cI went to see him once\r\nor twice\xe2\x80\x94nay, twice or thrice\xe2\x80\x94or by\xe2\x80\x99r lady, some four times\xe2\x80\x94and when he\r\ngot better, I tenderly brought him back to the fold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean, I restored him to the bosom of the club, and compassionating\r\nthe feebleness of his health and extreme lowness of his spirits, I\r\nrecommended him to \xe2\x80\x98take a little wine for his stomach\xe2\x80\x99s sake,\xe2\x80\x99 and,\r\nwhen he was sufficiently re-established, to embrace the media-via,\r\nni-jamais-ni-toujours plan\xe2\x80\x94not to kill himself like a fool, and not to\r\nabstain like a ninny\xe2\x80\x94in a word, to enjoy himself like a rational\r\ncreature, and do as I did; for, don\xe2\x80\x99t think, Helen, that I\xe2\x80\x99m a tippler;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m nothing at all of the kind, and never was, and never shall be. I\r\nvalue my comfort far too much. I see that a man cannot give himself up\r\nto drinking without being miserable one-half his days and mad the\r\nother; besides, I like to enjoy my life at all sides and ends, which\r\ncannot be done by one that suffers himself to be the slave of a single\r\npropensity\xe2\x80\x94and, moreover, drinking spoils one\xe2\x80\x99s good looks,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nconcluded, with a most conceited smile that ought to have provoked me\r\nmore than it did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did Lord Lowborough profit by your advice?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, in a manner. For a while he managed very well; indeed, he\r\nwas a model of moderation and prudence\xe2\x80\x94something too much so for the\r\ntastes of our wild community; but, somehow, Lowborough had not the gift\r\nof moderation: if he stumbled a little to one side, he must go down\r\nbefore he could right himself: if he overshot the mark one night, the\r\neffects of it rendered him so miserable the next day that he must\r\nrepeat the offence to mend it; and so on from day to day, till his\r\nclamorous conscience brought him to a stand. And then, in his sober\r\nmoments, he so bothered his friends with his remorse, and his terrors\r\nand woes, that they were obliged, in self-defence, to get him to drown\r\nhis sorrows in wine, or any more potent beverage that came to hand; and\r\nwhen his first scruples of conscience were overcome, he would need no\r\nmore persuading, he would often grow desperate, and be as great a\r\nblackguard as any of them could desire\xe2\x80\x94but only to lament his own\r\nunutterable wickedness and degradation the more when the fit was over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt last, one day when he and I were alone together, after pondering\r\nawhile in one of his gloomy, abstracted moods, with his arms folded and\r\nhis head sunk on his breast, he suddenly woke up, and vehemently\r\ngrasping my arm, said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Huntingdon, this won\xe2\x80\x99t do! I\xe2\x80\x99m resolved to have done with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What, are you going to shoot yourself?\xe2\x80\x99 said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No; I\xe2\x80\x99m going to reform.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Oh, _that\xe2\x80\x99s_ nothing new! You\xe2\x80\x99ve been going to reform these twelve\r\nmonths and more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes, but you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let me; and I was such a fool I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t live\r\nwithout you. But now I see what it is that keeps me back, and what\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwanted to save me; and I\xe2\x80\x99d compass sea and land to get it\xe2\x80\x94only I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nafraid there\xe2\x80\x99s no chance.\xe2\x80\x99 And he sighed as if his heart would break.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What is it, Lowborough?\xe2\x80\x99 said I, thinking he was fairly cracked at\r\nlast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98A wife,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered; \xe2\x80\x98for I can\xe2\x80\x99t live alone, because my own mind\r\ndistracts me, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t live with you, because you take the devil\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npart against me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x94I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes\xe2\x80\x94all of you do\xe2\x80\x94and you more than any of them, you know. But if I\r\ncould get a wife, with fortune enough to pay off my debts and set me\r\nstraight in the world\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98To be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And sweetness and goodness enough,\xe2\x80\x99 he continued, \xe2\x80\x98to make home\r\ntolerable, and to reconcile me to myself, I think I should do yet. I\r\nshall never be in love again, that\xe2\x80\x99s certain; but perhaps that would be\r\nno great matter, it would enable me to choose with my eyes open\xe2\x80\x94and I\r\nshould make a good husband in spite of it; but could any one be in love\r\nwith _me?_\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the question. With _your_ good looks and powers of\r\nfascination\xe2\x80\x99 (he was pleased to say), \xe2\x80\x98I might hope; but as it is,\r\nHuntingdon, do you think _any_body would take me\xe2\x80\x94ruined and wretched as\r\nI am?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes, certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Who?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Why, any neglected old maid, fast sinking in despair, would be\r\ndelighted to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said he\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98it must be somebody that I can love.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Why, you just said you never could be in love again!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Well, love is not the word\xe2\x80\x94but somebody that I can like. I\xe2\x80\x99ll search\r\nall England through, at all events!\xe2\x80\x99 he cried, with a sudden burst of\r\nhope, or desperation. \xe2\x80\x98Succeed or fail, it will be better than rushing\r\nheadlong to destruction at that d\xe2\x80\x94d club: so farewell to it and you.\r\nWhenever I meet you on honest ground or under a Christian roof, I shall\r\nbe glad to see you; but never more shall you entice me to that _devil\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nden!_\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was shameful language, but I shook hands with him, and we parted.\r\nHe kept his word; and from that time forward he has been a pattern of\r\npropriety, as far as I can tell; but till lately I have not had very\r\nmuch to do with him. He occasionally sought my company, but as\r\nfrequently shrunk from it, fearing lest I should wile him back to\r\ndestruction, and I found his not very entertaining, especially as he\r\nsometimes attempted to awaken my conscience and draw me from the\r\nperdition he considered himself to have escaped; but when I did happen\r\nto meet him, I seldom failed to ask after the progress of his\r\nmatrimonial efforts and researches, and, in general, he could give me\r\nbut a poor account. The mothers were repelled by his empty coffers and\r\nhis reputation for gambling, and the daughters by his cloudy brow and\r\nmelancholy temper\xe2\x80\x94besides, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand them; he wanted the\r\nspirit and assurance to carry his point.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI left him at it when I went to the continent; and on my return, at\r\nthe year\xe2\x80\x99s end, I found him still a disconsolate bachelor\xe2\x80\x94though,\r\ncertainly, looking somewhat less like an unblest exile from the tomb\r\nthan before. The young ladies had ceased to be afraid of him, and were\r\nbeginning to think him quite interesting; but the mammas were still\r\nunrelenting. It was about this time, Helen, that my good angel brought\r\nme into conjunction with you; and then I had eyes and ears for nobody\r\nelse. But, meantime, Lowborough became acquainted with our charming\r\nfriend, Miss Wilmot\xe2\x80\x94through the intervention of _his_ good angel, no\r\ndoubt he would tell you, though he did not dare to fix his hopes on one\r\nso courted and admired, till after they were brought into closer\r\ncontact here at Staningley, and she, in the absence of her other\r\nadmirers, indubitably courted his notice and held out every\r\nencouragement to his timid advances. Then, indeed, he began to hope for\r\na dawn of brighter days; and if, for a while, I darkened his prospects\r\nby standing between him and his sun\xe2\x80\x94and so nearly plunged him again\r\ninto the abyss of despair\xe2\x80\x94it only intensified his ardour and\r\nstrengthened his hopes when I chose to abandon the field in the pursuit\r\nof a brighter treasure. In a word, as I told you, he is fairly\r\nbesotted. At first, he could dimly perceive her faults, and they gave\r\nhim considerable uneasiness; but now his passion and her art together\r\nhave blinded him to everything but her perfections and his amazing good\r\nfortune. Last night he came to me brimful of his new-found felicity:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Huntingdon, I am not a castaway!\xe2\x80\x99 said he, seizing my hand and\r\nsqueezing it like a vice. \xe2\x80\x98There is happiness in store for me yet\xe2\x80\x94even\r\nin this life\xe2\x80\x94she loves me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 said I. \xe2\x80\x98Has she told you so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No, but I can no longer doubt it. Do you not see how pointedly kind\r\nand affectionate she is? And she knows the utmost extent of my poverty,\r\nand cares nothing about it! She knows all the folly and all the\r\nwickedness of my former life, and is not afraid to trust me\xe2\x80\x94and my rank\r\nand title are no allurements to her; for them she utterly disregards.\r\nShe is the most generous, high-minded being that can be conceived of.\r\nShe will save me, body and soul, from destruction. Already, she has\r\nennobled me in my own estimation, and made me three times better,\r\nwiser, greater than I was. Oh! if I had but known her before, how much\r\ndegradation and misery I should have been spared! But what have I done\r\nto deserve so magnificent a creature?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the cream of the jest,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Huntingdon, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cis,\r\nthat the artful minx loves nothing about him but his title and\r\npedigree, and \xe2\x80\x98that delightful old family seat.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe told me so herself; she said, \xe2\x80\x98As for the man himself, I\r\nthoroughly despise him; but then, I suppose, it is time to be making my\r\nchoice, and if I waited for some one capable of eliciting my esteem and\r\naffection, I should have to pass my life in single blessedness, for I\r\ndetest you all!\xe2\x80\x99 Ha, ha! I suspect she was wrong there; but, however,\r\nit is evident she has no love for _him_, poor fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you ought to tell him so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! and spoil all her plans and prospects, poor girl? No, no: that\r\nwould be a breach of confidence, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it, Helen? Ha, ha! Besides,\r\nit would break his heart.\xe2\x80\x9d And he laughed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Mr. Huntingdon, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you see so amazingly diverting\r\nin the matter; I see nothing to laugh at.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m laughing at _you_, just now, love,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, redoubling his\r\nmachinations.\r\n\r\nAnd leaving him to enjoy his merriment alone, I touched Ruby with the\r\nwhip, and cantered on to rejoin our companions; for we had been walking\r\nour horses all this time, and were consequently a long way behind.\r\nArthur was soon at my side again; but not disposed to talk to him, I\r\nbroke into a gallop. He did the same; and we did not slacken our pace\r\ntill we came up with Miss Wilmot and Lord Lowborough, which was within\r\nhalf a mile of the park-gates. I avoided all further conversation with\r\nhim till we came to the end of our ride, when I meant to jump off my\r\nhorse and vanish into the house, before he could offer his assistance;\r\nbut while I was disengaging my habit from the crutch, he lifted me off,\r\nand held me by both hands, asserting that he would not let me go till I\r\nhad forgiven him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have nothing to forgive,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have not injured _me_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, darling\xe2\x80\x94God forbid that I should! but you are angry because it was\r\nto me that Annabella confessed her lack of esteem for her lover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Arthur, it is not _that_ that displeases me: it is the whole\r\nsystem of your conduct towards your friend, and if you wish me to\r\nforget it, go now, and tell him what sort of a woman it is that he\r\nadores so madly, and on whom he has hung his hopes of future\r\nhappiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you, Helen, it would break his heart\xe2\x80\x94it would be the death of\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94besides being a scandalous trick to poor Annabella. There is no\r\nhelp for him now; he is past praying for. Besides, she may keep up the\r\ndeception to the end of the chapter; and then he will be just as happy\r\nin the illusion as if it were reality; or perhaps he will only discover\r\nhis mistake when he has ceased to love her; and if not, it is much\r\nbetter that the truth should dawn gradually upon him. So now, my angel,\r\nI hope I have made out a clear case, and fully convinced you that I\r\ncannot make the atonement you require. What other requisition have you\r\nto make? Speak, and I will gladly obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have none but this,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, as gravely as before: \xe2\x80\x9cthat, in future,\r\nyou will never make a jest of the sufferings of others, and always use\r\nyour influence with your friends for their own advantage against their\r\nevil propensities, instead of seconding their evil propensities against\r\nthemselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do my utmost,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto remember and perform the\r\ninjunctions of my angel monitress;\xe2\x80\x9d and after kissing both my gloved\r\nhands, he let me go.\r\n\r\nWhen I entered my room, I was surprised to see Annabella Wilmot\r\nstanding before my toilet-table, composedly surveying her features in\r\nthe glass, with one hand flirting her gold-mounted whip, and the other\r\nholding up her long habit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe certainly _is_ a magnificent creature!\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, as I beheld\r\nthat tall, finely developed figure, and the reflection of the handsome\r\nface in the mirror before me, with the glossy dark hair, slightly and\r\nnot ungracefully disordered by the breezy ride, the rich brown\r\ncomplexion glowing with exercise, and the black eyes sparkling with\r\nunwonted brilliance. On perceiving me, she turned round, exclaiming,\r\nwith a laugh that savoured more of malice than of mirth,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Helen! what _have_ you been doing so long? I came to tell you my\r\ngood fortune,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, regardless of Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s presence. \xe2\x80\x9cLord\r\nLowborough has proposed, and I have been graciously pleased to accept\r\nhim. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you envy me, dear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, love,\xe2\x80\x9d said I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cor him either,\xe2\x80\x9d I mentally added. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you like\r\nhim, Annabella?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike him! yes, to be sure\xe2\x80\x94over head and ears in love!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll make him a good wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my dear! And what besides do you hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you will both love each other, and both be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks; and I hope you will make a _very_ good wife to Mr.\r\nHuntingdon!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, with a queenly bow, and retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Miss! how could you say so to her!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rachel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay what?\xe2\x80\x9d replied I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that you hoped she would make him a good wife. I never heard such\r\na thing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I do hope it, or rather, I wish it; she\xe2\x80\x99s almost past hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure I hope he\xe2\x80\x99ll make _her_ a good husband.\r\nThey tell queer things about him downstairs. They were saying\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know, Rachel. I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard all about him; but he\xe2\x80\x99s reformed now. And\r\nthey have no business to tell tales about their masters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, mum\xe2\x80\x94or else, they _have_ said some things about Mr. Huntingdon\r\ntoo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t hear them, Rachel; they tell lies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, mum,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, quietly, as she went on arranging my hair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo _you_ believe them, Rachel?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, after a short pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Miss, not all. You know when a lot of servants gets together they\r\nlike to talk about their betters; and some, for a bit of swagger, likes\r\nto make it appear as though they knew more than they do, and to throw\r\nout hints and things just to astonish the others. But I think, if I was\r\nyou, Miss Helen, I\xe2\x80\x99d look _very_ well before I leaped. I do believe a\r\nyoung lady can\xe2\x80\x99t be too careful who she marries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course not,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; \xe2\x80\x9cbut be quick, will you, Rachel? I want to be\r\ndressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, indeed, I was anxious to be rid of the good woman, for I was in\r\nsuch a melancholy frame I could hardly keep the tears out of my eyes\r\nwhile she dressed me. It was not for Lord Lowborough\xe2\x80\x94it was not for\r\nAnnabella\xe2\x80\x94it was not for myself\xe2\x80\x94it was for Arthur Huntingdon that they\r\nrose.\r\n\r\n* * * * *\r\n\r\n\r\n13th.\xe2\x80\x94They are gone, and he is gone. We are to be parted for more than\r\ntwo months, above ten weeks! a long, long time to live and not to see\r\nhim. But he has promised to write often, and made me promise to write\r\nstill oftener, because he will be busy settling his affairs, and I\r\nshall have nothing better to do. Well, I think I shall always have\r\nplenty to say. But oh! for the time when we shall be always together,\r\nand can exchange our thoughts without the intervention of these cold\r\ngo-betweens, pen, ink, and paper!\r\n\r\n* * * * *\r\n\r\n\r\n22nd.\xe2\x80\x94I have had several letters from Arthur already. They are not\r\nlong, but passing sweet, and just like himself, full of ardent\r\naffection, and playful lively humour; but there is always a _but_ in\r\nthis imperfect world, and I do wish he would _sometimes_ be serious. I\r\ncannot get him to write or speak in real, solid earnest. I don\xe2\x80\x99t much\r\nmind it now, but if it be always so, what shall I do with the serious\r\npart of myself?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXIII\r\n\r\n\r\nFeb. 18, 1822.\xe2\x80\x94Early this morning Arthur mounted his hunter and set off\r\nin high glee to meet the \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 hounds. He will be away all day, and so I\r\nwill amuse myself with my neglected diary, if I can give that name to\r\nsuch an irregular composition. It is exactly four months since I opened\r\nit last.\r\n\r\nI am married now, and settled down as Mrs. Huntingdon of Grassdale\r\nManor. I have had eight weeks\xe2\x80\x99 experience of matrimony. And do I regret\r\nthe step I have taken? No, though I must confess, in my secret heart,\r\nthat Arthur is not what I thought him at first, and if I had known him\r\nin the beginning as thoroughly as I do now, I probably never should\r\nhave loved him, and if I loved him first, and then made the discovery,\r\nI fear I should have thought it my duty not to have married him. To be\r\nsure I might have known him, for every one was willing enough to tell\r\nme about him, and he himself was no accomplished hypocrite, but I was\r\nwilfully blind; and now, instead of regretting that I did not discern\r\nhis full character before I was indissolubly bound to him, I am _glad_,\r\nfor it has saved me a great deal of battling with my conscience, and a\r\ngreat deal of consequent trouble and pain; and, whatever I _ought_ to\r\nhave done, my duty now is plainly to love him and to cleave to him, and\r\nthis just tallies with my inclination.\r\n\r\nHe is very fond of me, almost _too_ fond. I could do with less\r\ncaressing and more rationality. I should like to be less of a pet and\r\nmore of a friend, if I might choose; but I won\xe2\x80\x99t complain of that: I am\r\nonly afraid his affection loses in depth where it gains in ardour. I\r\nsometimes liken it to a fire of dry twigs and branches compared with\r\none of solid coal, very bright and hot; but if it should burn itself\r\nout and leave nothing but ashes behind, what shall I do? But it won\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nit _shan_\xe2\x80\x99t, I am determined; and surely I have power to keep it alive.\r\nSo let me dismiss _that_ thought at once. But Arthur is selfish; I am\r\nconstrained to acknowledge that; and, indeed, the admission gives me\r\nless pain than might be expected, for, since _I_ love him so much, I\r\ncan easily forgive him for loving himself: he likes to be pleased, and\r\nit is my delight to please him; and when I regret this tendency of his,\r\nit is for his own sake, not for mine.\r\n\r\nThe first instance he gave was on the occasion of our bridal tour. He\r\nwanted to hurry it over, for all the continental scenes were already\r\nfamiliar to him: many had lost their interest in his eyes, and others\r\nhad never had anything to lose. The consequence was, that after a\r\nflying transit through part of France and part of Italy, I came back\r\nnearly as ignorant as I went, having made no acquaintance with persons\r\nand manners, and very little with things, my head swarming with a\r\nmotley confusion of objects and scenes; some, it is true, leaving a\r\ndeeper and more pleasing impression than others, but these embittered\r\nby the recollection that my emotions had not been shared by my\r\ncompanion, but that, on the contrary, when I had expressed a particular\r\ninterest in anything that I saw or desired to see, it had been\r\ndispleasing to him, inasmuch as it proved that I could take delight in\r\nanything disconnected with himself.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nAs for Paris, we only just touched at that, and he would not give me\r\ntime to see one-tenth of the beauties and interesting objects of Rome.\r\nHe wanted to get me home, he said, to have me all to himself, and to\r\nsee me safely installed as the mistress of Grassdale Manor, just as\r\nsingle-minded, as na\xc3\xafve, and piquante as I was; and as if I had been\r\nsome frail butterfly, he expressed himself fearful of rubbing the\r\nsilver off my wings by bringing me into contact with society,\r\nespecially that of Paris and Rome; and, more-over, he did not scruple\r\nto tell me that there were ladies in both places that would tear his\r\neyes out if they happened to meet him with me.\r\n\r\nOf course I was vexed at all this; but still it was less the\r\ndisappointment to myself that annoyed me, than the disappointment _in\r\nhim_, and the trouble I was at to frame excuses to my friends for\r\nhaving seen and observed so little, without imputing one particle of\r\nblame to my companion. But when we got home\xe2\x80\x94to my new, delightful\r\nhome\xe2\x80\x94I was so happy and he was so kind that I freely forgave him all;\r\nand I was beginning to think my lot _too_ happy, and my husband\r\nactually too good for me, if not too good for this world, when, on the\r\nsecond Sunday after our arrival, he shocked and horrified me by another\r\ninstance of his unreasonable exaction. We were walking home from the\r\nmorning service, for it was a fine frosty day, and as we are so near\r\nthe church, I had requested the carriage should not be used.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with unusual gravity, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not quite satisfied with\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI desired to know what was wrong.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut will you promise to reform if I tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if I can, and without offending a higher authority.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! there it is, you see: you don\xe2\x80\x99t love me with all your heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you, Arthur (at least I hope I don\xe2\x80\x99t): pray tell me\r\nwhat I have done or said amiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is nothing you have done or said; it is something that you _are:_\r\nyou are too religious. Now I like a woman to be religious, and I think\r\nyour piety one of your greatest charms; but then, like all other good\r\nthings, it may be carried too far. To my thinking, a woman\xe2\x80\x99s religion\r\nought not to lessen her devotion to her earthly lord. She should have\r\nenough to purify and etherealise her soul, but not enough to refine\r\naway her heart, and raise her above all human sympathies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd am _I_ above all human sympathies?\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, darling; but you are making more progress towards that saintly\r\ncondition than I like; for all these two hours I have been thinking of\r\nyou and wanting to catch your eye, and you were so absorbed in your\r\ndevotions that you had not even a glance to spare for me\xe2\x80\x94I declare it\r\nis enough to make one jealous of one\xe2\x80\x99s Maker\xe2\x80\x94which is very wrong, you\r\nknow; so don\xe2\x80\x99t excite such wicked passions again, for my soul\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will give my whole heart and soul to my Maker if I can,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand not one atom more of it to you than He allows. What are _you_,\r\nsir, that you should set yourself up as a god, and presume to dispute\r\npossession of my heart with Him to whom I owe all I have and all I am,\r\nevery blessing I ever did or ever can enjoy\xe2\x80\x94and yourself among the\r\nrest\xe2\x80\x94if you _are_ a blessing, which I am half inclined to doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be so hard upon me, Helen; and don\xe2\x80\x99t pinch my arm so: you are\r\nsqueezing your fingers into the bone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArthur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued I, relaxing my hold of his arm, \xe2\x80\x9cyou don\xe2\x80\x99t love me\r\nhalf as much as I do you; and yet, if you loved me far less than you\r\ndo, I would not complain, provided you loved your Maker more. I should\r\n_rejoice_ to see you at any time so deeply absorbed in your devotions\r\nthat you had not a single thought to spare for me. But, indeed, I\r\nshould lose nothing by the change, for the more you loved your God the\r\nmore deep and pure and true would be your love to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this he only laughed and kissed my hand, calling me a sweet\r\nenthusiast. Then taking off his hat, he added: \xe2\x80\x9cBut look here,\r\nHelen\xe2\x80\x94what can a man do with such a head as this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe head looked right enough, but when he placed my hand on the top of\r\nit, it sunk in a bed of curls, rather alarmingly low, especially in the\r\nmiddle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see I was not made to be a saint,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cIf God\r\nmeant me to be religious, why didn\xe2\x80\x99t He give me a proper organ of\r\nveneration?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are like the servant,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied, \xe2\x80\x9cwho, instead of employing his\r\none talent in his master\xe2\x80\x99s service, restored it to him unimproved,\r\nalleging, as an excuse, that he knew him \xe2\x80\x98to be a hard man, reaping\r\nwhere he had not sown, and gathering where he had not strawed.\xe2\x80\x99 Of him\r\nto whom less is given, less will be required, but our utmost exertions\r\nare required of us all. You are not without the capacity of veneration,\r\nand faith and hope, and conscience and reason, and every other\r\nrequisite to a Christian\xe2\x80\x99s character, if you choose to employ them; but\r\nall our talents increase in the using, and every faculty, both good and\r\nbad, strengthens by exercise: therefore, if you choose to use the bad,\r\nor those which tend to evil, till they become your masters, and neglect\r\nthe good till they dwindle away, you have only yourself to blame. But\r\nyou _have_ talents, Arthur\xe2\x80\x94natural endowments both of heart and mind\r\nand temper, such as many a better Christian would be glad to possess,\r\nif you would only employ them in God\xe2\x80\x99s service. I should never expect\r\nto see you a devotee, but it is quite possible to be a good Christian\r\nwithout ceasing to be a happy, merry-hearted man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak like an oracle, Helen, and all you say is indisputably true;\r\nbut listen here: I am hungry, and I see before me a good substantial\r\ndinner; I am told that if I abstain from this to-day I shall have a\r\nsumptuous feast to-morrow, consisting of all manner of dainties and\r\ndelicacies. Now, in the first place, I should be loth to wait till\r\nto-morrow when I have the means of appeasing my hunger already before\r\nme: in the second place, the solid viands of to-day are more to my\r\ntaste than the dainties that are promised me; in the third place, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t _see_ to-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s banquet, and how can I tell that it is not all\r\na fable, got up by the greasy-faced fellow that is advising me to\r\nabstain in order that he may have all the good victuals to himself? in\r\nthe fourth place, this table must be spread for somebody, and, as\r\nSolomon says, \xe2\x80\x98Who can eat, or who else can hasten hereunto more than\r\nI?\xe2\x80\x99 and finally, with your leave, I\xe2\x80\x99ll sit down and satisfy my cravings\r\nof to-day, and leave to-morrow to shift for itself\xe2\x80\x94who knows but what I\r\nmay secure both this and that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are not required to abstain from the substantial dinner of\r\nto-day: you are only advised to partake of these coarser viands in such\r\nmoderation as not to incapacitate you from enjoying the choicer banquet\r\nof to-morrow. If, regardless of that counsel, you choose to make a\r\nbeast of yourself now, and over-eat and over-drink yourself till you\r\nturn the good victuals into poison, who is to blame if, hereafter,\r\nwhile you are suffering the torments of yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s gluttony and\r\ndrunkenness, you see more temperate men sitting down to enjoy\r\nthemselves at that splendid entertainment which you are unable to\r\ntaste?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost true, my patron saint; but again, our friend Solomon says, \xe2\x80\x98There\r\nis nothing better for a man than to eat and to drink, and to be\r\nmerry.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd again,\xe2\x80\x9d returned I, \xe2\x80\x9che says, \xe2\x80\x98Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth;\r\nand walk in the ways of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes:\r\nbut know thou, that for all these things God will bring thee into\r\njudgment.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but, Helen, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I\xe2\x80\x99ve been very good these last few weeks.\r\nWhat have you seen amiss in me, and what would you have me to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing more than you do, Arthur: your actions are all right so far;\r\nbut I would have your thoughts changed; I would have you to fortify\r\nyourself against temptation, and not to call evil good, and good evil;\r\nI should wish you to think more deeply, to look further, and aim higher\r\nthan you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XXIV\r\n\r\n\r\nMarch 25th.\xe2\x80\x94Arthur is getting tired\xe2\x80\x94not of me, I trust, but of the\r\nidle, quiet life he leads\xe2\x80\x94and no wonder, for he has so few sources of\r\namusement: he never reads anything but newspapers and sporting\r\nmagazines; and when he sees me occupied with a book, he won\xe2\x80\x99t let me\r\nrest till I close it. In fine weather he generally manages to get\r\nthrough the time pretty well, but on rainy days, of which we have had a\r\ngood many of late, it is quite painful to witness his ennui. I do all I\r\ncan to amuse him, but it is impossible to get him to feel interested in\r\nwhat I most like to talk about, while, on the other hand, he likes to\r\ntalk about things that cannot interest me\xe2\x80\x94or even that annoy me\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthese please him\xe2\x80\x94the most of all: for his favourite amusement is to sit\r\nor loll beside me on the sofa, and tell me stories of his former\r\namours, always turning upon the ruin of some confiding girl or the\r\ncozening of some unsuspecting husband; and when I express my horror and\r\nindignation, he lays it all to the charge of jealousy, and laughs till\r\nthe tears run down his cheeks. I used to fly into passions or melt into\r\ntears at first, but seeing that his delight increased in proportion to\r\nmy anger and agitation, I have since endeavoured to suppress my\r\nfeelings and receive his revelations in the silence of calm contempt;\r\nbut still he reads the inward struggle in my face, and misconstrues my\r\nbitterness of soul for his unworthiness into the pangs of wounded\r\njealousy; and when he has sufficiently diverted himself with that, or\r\nfears my displeasure will become too serious for his comfort, he tries\r\nto kiss and soothe me into smiles again\xe2\x80\x94never were his caresses so\r\nlittle welcome as then! This is _double_ selfishness, displayed to me\r\nand to the victims of his former love. There are times when, with a\r\nmomentary pang\xe2\x80\x94a flash of wild dismay, I ask myself, \xe2\x80\x9cHelen, what have\r\nyou done?\xe2\x80\x9d But I rebuke the inward questioner, and repel the obtrusive\r\nthoughts that crowd upon me; for were he ten times as sensual and\r\nimpenetrable to good and lofty thoughts, I well know I have no right to\r\ncomplain. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t and won\xe2\x80\x99t complain. I do and will love him still;\r\nand I do not and will not regret that I have linked my fate with his.\r\n\r\nApril 4th.\xe2\x80\x94We have had a downright quarrel. The particulars are as\r\nfollows: Arthur had told me, at different intervals, the whole story of\r\nhis intrigue with Lady F\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, which I would not believe before. It was\r\nsome consolation, however, to find that in this instance the lady had\r\nbeen more to blame than he, for he was very young at the time, and she\r\nhad decidedly made the first advances, if what he said was true. I\r\nhated her for it, for it seemed as if she had chiefly contributed to\r\nhis corruption; and when he was beginning to talk about her the other\r\nday, I begged he would not mention her, for I detested the very sound\r\nof her name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot because you loved her, Arthur, mind, but because she injured you\r\nand deceived her husband, and was altogether a very abominable woman,\r\nwhom you ought to be ashamed to mention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he defended her by saying that she had a doting old husband, whom\r\nit was impossible to love.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why did she marry him?\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor his money,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen that was another crime, and her solemn promise to love and honour\r\nhim was another, that only increased the enormity of the last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are too severe upon the poor lady,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed he. \xe2\x80\x9cBut never mind,\r\nHelen, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care for her now; and I never loved any of them half as\r\nmuch as I do you, so you needn\xe2\x80\x99t fear to be forsaken like them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you had told me these things before, Arthur, I never should have\r\ngiven you the chance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t_ you, my darling?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost certainly not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe laughed incredulously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could convince you of it now!\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, starting up from\r\nbeside him: and for the first time in my life, and I hope the last, I\r\nwished I had not married him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, more gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know that if I believed you now\r\nI should be very angry? but thank heaven I don\xe2\x80\x99t. Though you stand\r\nthere with your white face and flashing eyes, looking at me like a very\r\ntigress, I know the heart within you perhaps a trifle better than you\r\nknow it yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout another word I left the room and locked myself up in my own\r\nchamber. In about half an hour he came to the door, and first he tried\r\nthe handle, then he knocked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you let me in, Helen?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cNo; you have displeased me,\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x9cand I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to see your face or hear your voice again\r\ntill the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused a moment as if dumfounded or uncertain how to answer such a\r\nspeech, and then turned and walked away. This was only an hour after\r\ndinner: I knew he would find it very dull to sit alone all the evening;\r\nand this considerably softened my resentment, though it did not make me\r\nrelent. I was determined to show him that my heart was not his slave,\r\nand I could live without him if I chose; and I sat down and wrote a\r\nlong letter to my aunt, of course telling her nothing of all this. Soon\r\nafter ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock I heard him come up again, but he passed my door and\r\nwent straight to his own dressing-room, where he shut himself in for\r\nthe night.\r\n\r\nI was rather anxious to see how he would meet me in the morning, and\r\nnot a little disappointed to behold him enter the breakfast-room with a\r\ncareless smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you cross still, Helen?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, approaching as if to salute me.\r\nI coldly turned to the table, and began to pour out the coffee,\r\nobserving that he was rather late.\r\n\r\nHe uttered a low whistle and sauntered away to the window, where he\r\nstood for some minutes looking out upon the pleasing prospect of sullen\r\ngrey clouds, streaming rain, soaking lawn, and dripping leafless trees,\r\nand muttering execrations on the weather, and then sat down to\r\nbreakfast. While taking his coffee he muttered it was \xe2\x80\x9cd\xe2\x80\x94d cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should not have left it so long,\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\nHe made no answer, and the meal was concluded in silence. It was a\r\nrelief to both when the letter-bag was brought in. It contained upon\r\nexamination a newspaper and one or two letters for him, and a couple of\r\nletters for me, which he tossed across the table without a remark. One\r\nwas from my brother, the other from Milicent Hargrave, who is now in\r\nLondon with her mother. His, I think, were business letters, and\r\napparently not much to his mind, for he crushed them into his pocket\r\nwith some muttered expletives that I should have reproved him for at\r\nany other time. The paper he set before him, and pretended to be deeply\r\nabsorbed in its contents during the remainder of breakfast, and a\r\nconsiderable time after.\r\n\r\nThe reading and answering of my letters, and the direction of household\r\nconcerns, afforded me ample employment for the morning: after lunch I\r\ngot my drawing, and from dinner till bed-time I read. Meanwhile, poor\r\nArthur was sadly at a loss for something to amuse him or to occupy his\r\ntime. He wanted to appear as busy and as unconcerned as I did. Had the\r\nweather at all permitted, he would doubtless have ordered his horse and\r\nset off to some distant region, no matter where, immediately after\r\nbreakfast, and not returned till night: had there been a lady anywhere\r\nwithin reach, of any age between fifteen and forty-five, he would have\r\nsought revenge and found employment in getting up, or trying to get up,\r\na desperate flirtation with her; but being, to my private satisfaction,\r\nentirely cut off from both these sources of diversion, his sufferings\r\nwere truly deplorable. When he had done yawning over his paper and\r\nscribbling short answers to his shorter letters, he spent the remainder\r\nof the morning and the whole of the afternoon in fidgeting about from\r\nroom to room, watching the clouds, cursing the rain, alternately\r\npetting and teasing and abusing his dogs, sometimes lounging on the\r\nsofa with a book that he could not force himself to read, and very\r\noften fixedly gazing at me when he thought I did not perceive it, with\r\nthe vain hope of detecting some traces of tears, or some tokens of\r\nremorseful anguish in my face. But I managed to preserve an undisturbed\r\nthough grave serenity throughout the day. I was not really angry: I\r\nfelt for him all the time, and longed to be reconciled; but I\r\ndetermined he should make the first advances, or at least show some\r\nsigns of an humble and contrite spirit first; for, if I began, it would\r\nonly minister to his self-conceit, increase his arrogance, and quite\r\ndestroy the lesson I wanted to give him.\r\n\r\nHe made a long stay in the dining-room after dinner, and, I fear, took\r\nan unusual quantity of wine, but not enough to loosen his tongue: for\r\nwhen he came in and found me quietly occupied with my book, too busy to\r\nlift my head on his entrance, he merely murmured an expression of\r\nsuppressed disapprobation, and, shutting the door with a bang, went and\r\nstretched himself at full length on the sofa, and composed himself to\r\nsleep. But his favourite cocker, Dash, that had been lying at my feet,\r\ntook the liberty of jumping upon him and beginning to lick his face. He\r\nstruck it off with a smart blow, and the poor dog squeaked and ran\r\ncowering back to me.
