Her pale lips quivered, and her fingers trembled with\r\nagitation, as she nervously entwined them in the hair-chain to which\r\nwas appended her small gold watch\xe2\x80\x94the only thing of value she had\r\npermitted herself to keep. I had said an unjust and cruel thing; but I\r\nmust needs follow it up with something worse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Helen!\xe2\x80\x9d I began in a soft, low tone, not daring to raise my eyes\r\nto her face, \xe2\x80\x9cthat man is not your husband: in the sight of heaven he\r\nhas forfeited all claim to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d She seized my arm with a grasp of\r\nstartling energy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Gilbert, don\xe2\x80\x99t!_\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, in a tone that would have pierced a\r\nheart of adamant. \xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t _you_ attempt these arguments!\r\nNo _fiend_ could torture me like this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t, I won\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said I, gently laying my hand on hers; almost as\r\nmuch alarmed at her vehemence as ashamed of my own misconduct.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstead of acting like a true friend,\xe2\x80\x9d continued she, breaking from\r\nme, and throwing herself into the old arm-chair, \xe2\x80\x9cand helping me with\r\nall your might\xe2\x80\x94or rather taking your own part in the struggle of right\r\nagainst passion\xe2\x80\x94you leave all the burden to me;\xe2\x80\x94and not satisfied with\r\nthat, you do your utmost to fight against me\xe2\x80\x94when you know that!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\npaused, and hid her face in her handkerchief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me, Helen!\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded I. \xe2\x80\x9cI will never utter another word on the\r\nsubject. But may we not still meet as friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will not do,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, mournfully shaking her head; and then\r\nshe raised her eyes to mine, with a mildly reproachful look that seemed\r\nto say, \xe2\x80\x9cYou must know that as well as I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen what _must_ we do?\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, passionately. But immediately I\r\nadded in a quieter tone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll do whatever you desire; only _don\xe2\x80\x99t_ say\r\nthat this meeting is to be our last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why not? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that every time we meet the thoughts of\r\nthe final parting will become more painful? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you _feel_ that every\r\ninterview makes us dearer to each other than the last?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe utterance of this last question was hurried and low, and the\r\ndowncast eyes and burning blush too plainly showed that _she_, at\r\nleast, had felt it. It was scarcely prudent to make such an admission,\r\nor to add\xe2\x80\x94as she presently did\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI have power to bid you go, now:\r\nanother time it might be different,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but I was not base enough to\r\nattempt to take advantage of her candour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we may write,\xe2\x80\x9d I timidly suggested. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will not deny me that\r\nconsolation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can hear of each other through my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour brother!\xe2\x80\x9d A pang of remorse and shame shot through me. She had\r\nnot heard of the injury he had sustained at my hands; and I had not the\r\ncourage to tell her. \xe2\x80\x9cYour brother will not help us,\xe2\x80\x9d I said: \xe2\x80\x9che would\r\nhave all communion between us to be entirely at an end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he would be right, I suppose. As a friend of both, he would wish\r\nus both well; and every friend would tell us it was our interest, as\r\nwell as our duty, to forget each other, though we might not see it\r\nourselves. But don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, Gilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, smiling sadly at\r\nmy manifest discomposure; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is little chance of my forgetting you.\r\nBut I did not mean that Frederick should be the means of transmitting\r\nmessages between us\xe2\x80\x94only that each might know, through him, of the\r\nother\xe2\x80\x99s welfare;\xe2\x80\x94and more than this ought not to be: for you are young,\r\nGilbert, and you ought to marry\xe2\x80\x94and will some time, though you may\r\nthink it impossible now: and though I hardly can say I wish you to\r\nforget me, I know it is right that you should, both for your own\r\nhappiness, and that of your future wife;\xe2\x80\x94and therefore I must and will\r\nwish it,\xe2\x80\x9d she added resolutely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are young too, Helen,\xe2\x80\x9d I boldly replied; \xe2\x80\x9cand when that\r\nprofligate scoundrel has run through his career, you will give your\r\nhand to me\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll wait till then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she would not leave me this support. Independently of the moral\r\nevil of basing our hopes upon the death of another, who, if unfit for\r\nthis world, was at least no less so for the next, and whose\r\namelioration would thus become our bane and his greatest transgression\r\nour greatest benefit,\xe2\x80\x94she maintained it to be madness: many men of Mr.\r\nHuntingdon\xe2\x80\x99s habits had lived to a ripe though miserable old age. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nif I,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cam young in years, I am old in sorrow; but even if\r\ntrouble should fail to kill me before vice destroys him, think, if he\r\nreached but fifty years or so, would you wait twenty or fifteen\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nvague uncertainty and suspense\xe2\x80\x94through all the prime of youth and\r\nmanhood\xe2\x80\x94and marry at last a woman faded and worn as I shall be\xe2\x80\x94without\r\never having seen me from this day to that?\xe2\x80\x94You would not,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\ncontinued, interrupting my earnest protestations of unfailing\r\nconstancy,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cor if you would, you should not. Trust me, Gilbert; in this\r\nmatter I know better than you. You think me cold and stony-hearted, and\r\nyou may, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t, Helen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind: you might if you would: but I have not spent my\r\nsolitude in utter idleness, and I am not speaking now from the impulse\r\nof the moment, as you do. I have thought of all these matters again and\r\nagain; I have argued these questions with myself, and pondered well our\r\npast, and present, and future career; and, believe me, I have come to\r\nthe right conclusion at last. Trust my words rather than your own\r\nfeelings now, and in a few years you will see that I was right\xe2\x80\x94though\r\nat present I hardly can see it myself,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured with a sigh as she\r\nrested her head on her hand. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd don\xe2\x80\x99t argue against me any more: all\r\nyou can say has been already said by my own heart and refuted by my\r\nreason. It was hard enough to combat those suggestions as they were\r\nwhispered within me; in your mouth they are ten times worse, and if you\r\nknew how much they pain me you would cease at once, I know. If you knew\r\nmy present feelings, you would even try to relieve them at the expense\r\nof your own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go\xe2\x80\x94in a minute, if _that_ can relieve you\xe2\x80\x94and NEVER return!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid I, with bitter emphasis. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, if we may never meet, and never\r\nhope to meet again, is it a crime to exchange our thoughts by letter?\r\nMay not kindred spirits meet, and mingle in communion, whatever be the\r\nfate and circumstances of their earthly tenements?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may, they may!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, with a momentary burst of glad\r\nenthusiasm. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought of that too, Gilbert, but I feared to mention\r\nit, because I feared you would not understand my views upon the\r\nsubject. I fear it even now\xe2\x80\x94I fear any kind friend would tell us we are\r\n_both_ deluding ourselves with the idea of keeping up a spiritual\r\nintercourse without hope or prospect of anything further\xe2\x80\x94without\r\nfostering vain regrets and hurtful aspirations, and feeding thoughts\r\nthat should be sternly and pitilessly left to perish of inanition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind our kind friends: if they can part our bodies, it is\r\nenough; in God\xe2\x80\x99s name, let them not sunder our souls!\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, in\r\nterror lest she should deem it her duty to deny us this last remaining\r\nconsolation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut no letters can pass between us here,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cwithout giving\r\nfresh food for scandal; and when I departed, I had intended that my new\r\nabode should be unknown to you as to the rest of the world; not that I\r\nshould doubt your word if you promised not to visit me, but I thought\r\nyou would be more tranquil in your own mind if you knew you could not\r\ndo it, and likely to find less difficulty in abstracting yourself from\r\nme if you could not picture my situation to your mind. But listen,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid she, smilingly putting up her finger to check my impatient reply:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cin six months you shall hear from Frederick precisely where I am; and\r\nif you still retain your wish to write to me, and think you can\r\nmaintain a correspondence all thought, all spirit\xe2\x80\x94such as disembodied\r\nsouls or unimpassioned friends, at least, might hold,\xe2\x80\x94write, and I will\r\nanswer you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix months!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to give your present ardour time to cool, and try the truth and\r\nconstancy of your soul\xe2\x80\x99s love for mine. And now, enough has been said\r\nbetween us. Why can\xe2\x80\x99t we part at once?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed she, almost wildly,\r\nafter a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause, as she suddenly rose from her chair, with her\r\nhands resolutely clasped together. I thought it was my duty to go\r\nwithout delay; and I approached and half extended my hand as if to take\r\nleave\xe2\x80\x94she grasped it in silence. But this thought of final separation\r\nwas too intolerable: it seemed to squeeze the blood out of my heart;\r\nand my feet were glued to the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd must we never meet again?\xe2\x80\x9d I murmured, in the anguish of my soul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall meet in heaven. Let us think of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said she in a tone of\r\ndesperate calmness; but her eyes glittered wildly, and her face was\r\ndeadly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not as we are now,\xe2\x80\x9d I could not help replying. \xe2\x80\x9cIt gives me little\r\nconsolation to think I shall next behold you as a disembodied spirit,\r\nor an altered being, with a frame perfect and glorious, but not like\r\nthis!\xe2\x80\x94and a heart, perhaps, entirely estranged from me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Gilbert, there is perfect love in heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_So_ perfect, I suppose, that it soars above distinctions, and you\r\nwill have no closer sympathy with me than with any one of the ten\r\nthousand thousand angels and the innumerable multitude of happy spirits\r\nround us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever I am, you will be the same, and, therefore, cannot possibly\r\nregret it; and whatever that change may be we know it must be for the\r\nbetter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if I am to be so changed that I shall cease to adore you with my\r\nwhole heart and soul, and love you beyond every other creature, I shall\r\nnot be myself; and though, if ever I win heaven at all, I must, I know,\r\nbe infinitely better and happier than I am now, my earthly nature\r\ncannot rejoice in the anticipation of such beatitude, from which itself\r\nand its chief joy must be excluded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your love _all_ earthly, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I am supposing we shall have no more intimate communion with\r\neach other than with the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf so, it will be because we love them more, and not each other less.\r\nIncrease of love brings increase of happiness, when it is mutual, and\r\npure as that will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut can _you_, Helen, contemplate with delight this prospect of losing\r\nme in a sea of glory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI own I cannot; but we know not that it will be so;\xe2\x80\x94and I do know that\r\nto regret the exchange of earthly pleasures for the joys of heaven, is\r\nas if the grovelling caterpillar should lament that it must one day\r\nquit the nibbled leaf to soar aloft and flutter through the air, roving\r\nat will from flower to flower, sipping sweet honey from their cups, or\r\nbasking in their sunny petals. If these little creatures knew how great\r\na change awaited them, no doubt they would regret it; but would not all\r\nsuch sorrow be misplaced? And if that illustration will not move you,\r\nhere is another:\xe2\x80\x94We are children now; we feel as children, and we\r\nunderstand as children; and when we are told that men and women do not\r\nplay with toys, and that our companions will one day weary of the\r\ntrivial sports and occupations that interest them and us so deeply now,\r\nwe cannot help being saddened at the thoughts of such an alteration,\r\nbecause we cannot conceive that as we grow up our own minds will become\r\nso enlarged and elevated that we ourselves shall then regard as\r\ntrifling those objects and pursuits we now so fondly cherish, and that,\r\nthough our companions will no longer join us in those childish\r\npastimes, they will drink with us at other fountains of delight, and\r\nmingle their souls with ours in higher aims and nobler occupations\r\nbeyond our present comprehension, but not less deeply relished or less\r\ntruly good for that, while yet both we and they remain essentially the\r\nsame individuals as before. But, Gilbert, can you really derive no\r\nconsolation from the thought that we may meet together where there is\r\nno more pain and sorrow, no more striving against sin, and struggling\r\nof the spirit against the flesh; where both will behold the same\r\nglorious truths, and drink exalted and supreme felicity from the same\r\nfountain of light and goodness\xe2\x80\x94that Being whom both will worship with\r\nthe same intensity of holy ardour\xe2\x80\x94and where pure and happy creatures\r\nboth will love with the same divine affection? If you cannot, never\r\nwrite to me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen, I can! if faith would never fail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed she, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile this hope is strong within us\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will part,\xe2\x80\x9d I cried. \xe2\x80\x9cYou shall not have the pain of another effort\r\nto dismiss me. I will go at once; but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did not put my request in words: she understood it instinctively, and\r\n_this_ time she yielded too\xe2\x80\x94or rather, there was nothing so deliberate\r\nas requesting or yielding in the matter: there was a sudden impulse\r\nthat neither could resist. One moment I stood and looked into her face,\r\nthe next I held her to my heart, and we seemed to grow together in a\r\nclose embrace from which no physical or mental force could rend us. A\r\nwhispered \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cGo\xe2\x80\x94go!\xe2\x80\x9d was all she said; but while she\r\nspoke she held me so fast that, without violence, I could not have\r\nobeyed her. At length, however, by some heroic effort, we tore\r\nourselves apart, and I rushed from the house.\r\n\r\nI have a confused remembrance of seeing little Arthur running up the\r\ngarden-walk to meet me, and of bolting over the wall to avoid him\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nsubsequently running down the steep fields, clearing the stone fences\r\nand hedges as they came in my way, till I got completely out of sight\r\nof the old hall and down to the bottom of the hill; and then of long\r\nhours spent in bitter tears and lamentations, and melancholy musings in\r\nthe lonely valley, with the eternal music in my ears, of the west wind\r\nrushing through the overshadowing trees, and the brook babbling and\r\ngurgling along its stony bed; my eyes, for the most part, vacantly\r\nfixed on the deep, chequered shades restlessly playing over the bright\r\nsunny grass at my feet, where now and then a withered leaf or two would\r\ncome dancing to share the revelry; but my heart was away up the hill in\r\nthat dark room where she was weeping desolate and alone\xe2\x80\x94she whom I was\r\nnot to comfort, not to see again, till years or suffering had overcome\r\nus both, and torn our spirits from their perishing abodes of clay.\r\n\r\nThere was little business done that day, you may be sure. The farm was\r\nabandoned to the labourers, and the labourers were left to their own\r\ndevices. But one duty must be attended to; I had not forgotten my\r\nassault upon Frederick Lawrence; and I must see him to apologise for\r\nthe unhappy deed. I would fain have put it off till the morrow; but\r\nwhat if he should denounce me to his sister in the meantime? No, no! I\r\nmust ask his pardon to-day, and entreat him to be lenient in his\r\naccusation, if the revelation must be made. I deferred it, however,\r\ntill the evening, when my spirits were more composed, and when\xe2\x80\x94oh,\r\nwonderful perversity of human nature!\xe2\x80\x94some faint germs of indefinite\r\nhopes were beginning to rise in my mind; not that I intended to cherish\r\nthem, after all that had been said on the subject, but there they must\r\nlie for a while, uncrushed though not encouraged, till I had learnt to\r\nlive without them.\r\n\r\nArrived at Woodford, the young squire\xe2\x80\x99s abode, I found no little\r\ndifficulty in obtaining admission to his presence. The servant that\r\nopened the door told me his master was very ill, and seemed to think it\r\ndoubtful whether he would be able to see me. I was not going to be\r\nbaulked, however. I waited calmly in the hall to be announced, but\r\ninwardly determined to take no denial. The message was such as I\r\nexpected\xe2\x80\x94a polite intimation that Mr. Lawrence could see no one; he was\r\nfeverish, and must not be disturbed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall not disturb him long,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I must see him for a\r\nmoment: it is on business of importance that I wish to speak to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell him, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. And I advanced further into the\r\nhall and followed him nearly to the door of the apartment where his\r\nmaster was\xe2\x80\x94for it seemed he was not in bed. The answer returned was\r\nthat Mr. Lawrence hoped I would be so good as to leave a message or a\r\nnote with the servant, as he could attend to no business at present.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe may as well see me as you,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; and, stepping past the\r\nastonished footman, I boldly rapped at the door, entered, and closed it\r\nbehind me. The room was spacious and handsomely furnished\xe2\x80\x94very\r\ncomfortably, too, for a bachelor. A clear, red fire was burning in the\r\npolished grate: a superannuated greyhound, given up to idleness and\r\ngood living, lay basking before it on the thick, soft rug, on one\r\ncorner of which, beside the sofa, sat a smart young springer, looking\r\nwistfully up in its master\xe2\x80\x99s face\xe2\x80\x94perhaps asking permission to share\r\nhis couch, or, it might be, only soliciting a caress from his hand or a\r\nkind word from his lips. The invalid himself looked very interesting as\r\nhe lay reclining there, in his elegant dressing-gown, with a silk\r\nhandkerchief bound across his temples. His usually pale face was\r\nflushed and feverish; his eyes were half closed, until he became\r\nsensible of my presence\xe2\x80\x94and then he opened them wide enough: one hand\r\nwas thrown listlessly over the back of the sofa, and held a small\r\nvolume, with which, apparently, he had been vainly attempting to\r\nbeguile the weary hours. He dropped it, however, in his start of\r\nindignant surprise as I advanced into the room and stood before him on\r\nthe rug. He raised himself on his pillows, and gazed upon me with equal\r\ndegrees of nervous horror, anger, and amazement depicted on his\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Markham, I scarcely expected this!\xe2\x80\x9d he said; and the blood left\r\nhis cheek as he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you didn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d answered I; \xe2\x80\x9cbut be quiet a minute, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell\r\nyou what I came for.\xe2\x80\x9d Unthinkingly, I advanced a step or two nearer. He\r\nwinced at my approach, with an expression of aversion and instinctive\r\nphysical fear anything but conciliatory to my feelings. I stepped back,\r\nhowever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake your story a short one,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, putting his hand on the small\r\nsilver bell that stood on the table beside him, \xe2\x80\x9cor I shall be obliged\r\nto call for assistance. I am in no state to bear your brutalities now,\r\nor your presence either.\xe2\x80\x9d And in truth the moisture started from his\r\npores and stood on his pale forehead like dew.\r\n\r\nSuch a reception was hardly calculated to diminish the difficulties of\r\nmy unenviable task. It must be performed however, in some fashion; and\r\nso I plunged into it at once, and floundered through it as I could.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth is, Lawrence,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not acted quite correctly\r\ntowards you of late\xe2\x80\x94especially on this last occasion; and I\xe2\x80\x99m come\r\nto\xe2\x80\x94in short, to express my regret for what has been done, and to beg\r\nyour pardon. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t choose to grant it,\xe2\x80\x9d I added hastily, not\r\nliking the aspect of his face, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s no matter; only _I\xe2\x80\x99ve_ done _my_\r\nduty\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s easily done,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, with a faint smile bordering on a\r\nsneer: \xe2\x80\x9cto abuse your friend and knock him on the head without any\r\nassignable cause, and then tell him the deed was not quite correct, but\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s no matter whether he pardons it or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgot to tell you that it was in consequence of a\r\nmistake,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94muttered I. \xe2\x80\x9cI should have made a very handsome apology, but\r\nyou provoked me so confoundedly with your\xe2\x80\x94. Well, I suppose it\xe2\x80\x99s my\r\nfault. The fact is, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know that you were Mrs. Graham\xe2\x80\x99s brother,\r\nand I saw and heard some things respecting your conduct towards her\r\nwhich were calculated to awaken unpleasant suspicions, that, allow me\r\nto say, a little candour and confidence on your part might have\r\nremoved; and, at last, I chanced to overhear a part of a conversation\r\nbetween you and her that made me think I had a right to hate you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how came you to know that I was her brother?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, in some\r\nanxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe told me herself. She told me all. _She_ knew I might be trusted.\r\nBut you needn\xe2\x80\x99t disturb yourself about _that_, Mr. Lawrence, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nseen the last of her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe last! Is she gone, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but she has bid adieu to me, and I have promised never to go near\r\nthat house again while she inhabits it.\xe2\x80\x9d I could have groaned aloud at\r\nthe bitter thoughts awakened by this turn in the discourse. But I only\r\nclenched my hands and stamped my foot upon the rug. My companion,\r\nhowever, was evidently relieved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have done right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a tone of unqualified approbation,\r\nwhile his face brightened into almost a sunny expression. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd as for\r\nthe mistake, I am sorry for both our sakes that it should have\r\noccurred. Perhaps you can forgive my want of candour, and remember, as\r\nsome partial mitigation of the offence, how little encouragement to\r\nfriendly confidence you have given me of late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes\xe2\x80\x94I remember it all: nobody can blame me more than I blame\r\nmyself in my own heart; at any rate, nobody can regret more sincerely\r\nthan I do the result of my _brutality_, as you rightly term it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind that,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, faintly smiling; \xe2\x80\x9clet us forget all\r\nunpleasant words on both sides, as well as deeds, and consign to\r\noblivion everything that we have cause to regret. Have you any\r\nobjection to take my hand, or you\xe2\x80\x99d rather not?\xe2\x80\x9d It trembled through\r\nweakness as he held it out, and dropped before I had time to catch it\r\nand give it a hearty squeeze, which he had not the strength to return.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dry and burning your hand is, Lawrence,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are really\r\nill, and I have made you worse by all this talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is nothing; only a cold got by the rain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy doing, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind that. But tell me, did you mention this affair to my\r\nsister?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo confess the truth, I had not the courage to do so; but when you\r\ntell her, will you just say that I deeply regret it, and\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, never fear! I shall say nothing against you, as long as you keep\r\nyour good resolution of remaining aloof from her. She has not heard of\r\nmy illness, then, that you are aware of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad of that, for I have been all this time tormenting myself with\r\nthe fear that somebody would tell her I was dying, or desperately ill,\r\nand she would be either distressing herself on account of her inability\r\nto hear from me or do me any good, or perhaps committing the madness of\r\ncoming to see me. I must contrive to let her know something about it,\r\nif I can,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, reflectively, \xe2\x80\x9cor she will be hearing some\r\nsuch story. Many would be glad to tell her such news, just to see how\r\nshe would take it; and then she might expose herself to fresh scandal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had told her,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it were not for my promise, I\r\nwould tell her now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means! I am not dreaming of that;\xe2\x80\x94but if I were to write a short\r\nnote, now, not mentioning you, Markham, but just giving a slight\r\naccount of my illness, by way of excuse for my not coming to see her,\r\nand to put her on her guard against any exaggerated reports she may\r\nhear,\xe2\x80\x94and address it in a disguised hand\xe2\x80\x94would you do me the favour to\r\nslip it into the post-office as you pass? for I dare not trust any of\r\nthe servants in such a case.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMost willingly I consented, and immediately brought him his desk. There\r\nwas little need to disguise his hand, for the poor fellow seemed to\r\nhave considerable difficulty in writing at all, so as to be legible.\r\nWhen the note was done, I thought it time to retire, and took leave,\r\nafter asking if there was anything in the world I could do for him,\r\nlittle or great, in the way of alleviating his sufferings, and\r\nrepairing the injury I had done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have already done much towards it; you have done\r\nmore for me than the most skilful physician could do: for you have\r\nrelieved my mind of two great burdens\xe2\x80\x94anxiety on my sister\xe2\x80\x99s account,\r\nand deep regret upon your own: for I do believe these two sources of\r\ntorment have had more effect in working me up into a fever than\r\nanything else; and I am persuaded I shall soon recover now. There is\r\none more thing you can do for me, and that is, come and see me now and\r\nthen\xe2\x80\x94for you see I am very lonely here, and I promise your entrance\r\nshall not be disputed again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI engaged to do so, and departed with a cordial pressure of the hand. I\r\nposted the letter on my way home, most manfully resisting the\r\ntemptation of dropping in a word from myself at the same time.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLVI\r\n\r\n\r\nI felt strongly tempted, at times, to enlighten my mother and sister on\r\nthe real character and circumstances of the persecuted tenant of\r\nWildfell Hall, and at first I greatly regretted having omitted to ask\r\nthat lady\xe2\x80\x99s permission to do so; but, on due reflection, I considered\r\nthat if it were known to them, it could not long remain a secret to the\r\nMillwards and Wilsons, and such was my present appreciation of Eliza\r\nMillward\xe2\x80\x99s disposition, that, if once she got a clue to the story, I\r\nshould fear she would soon find means to enlighten Mr. Huntingdon upon\r\nthe place of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s retreat. I would therefore wait patiently till\r\nthese weary six months were over, and then, when the fugitive had found\r\nanother home, and I was permitted to write to her, I would beg to be\r\nallowed to clear her name from these vile calumnies: at present I must\r\ncontent myself with simply asserting that I knew them to be false, and\r\nwould prove it some day, to the shame of those who slandered her. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t think anybody believed me, but everybody soon learned to avoid\r\ninsinuating a word against her, or even mentioning her name in my\r\npresence. They thought I was so madly infatuated by the seductions of\r\nthat unhappy lady that I was determined to support her in the very face\r\nof reason; and meantime I grow insupportably morose and misanthropical\r\nfrom the idea that every one I met was harbouring unworthy thoughts of\r\nthe supposed Mrs. Graham, and would express them if he dared. My poor\r\nmother was quite distressed about me; but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it\xe2\x80\x94at least I\r\nthought I could not, though sometimes I felt a pang of remorse for my\r\nundutiful conduct to her, and made an effort to amend, attended with\r\nsome partial success; and indeed I was generally more humanised in my\r\ndemeanour to her than to any one else, Mr. Lawrence excepted. Rose and\r\nFergus usually shunned my presence; and it was well they did, for I was\r\nnot fit company for them, nor they for me, under the present\r\ncircumstances.\r\n\r\nMrs. Huntingdon did not leave Wildfell Hall till above two months after\r\nour farewell interview. During that time she never appeared at church,\r\nand I never went near the house: I only knew she was still there by her\r\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s brief answers to my many and varied inquiries respecting her.\r\nI was a very constant and attentive visitor to him throughout the whole\r\nperiod of his illness and convalescence; not only from the interest I\r\ntook in his recovery, and my desire to cheer him up and make the utmost\r\npossible amends for my former \xe2\x80\x9cbrutality,\xe2\x80\x9d but from my growing\r\nattachment to himself, and the increasing pleasure I found in his\r\nsociety\xe2\x80\x94partly from his increased cordiality to me, but chiefly on\r\naccount of his close connection, both in blood and in affection, with\r\nmy adored Helen. I loved him for it better than I liked to express: and\r\nI took a secret delight in pressing those slender white fingers, so\r\nmarvellously like her own, considering he was not a woman, and in\r\nwatching the passing changes in his fair, pale features, and observing\r\nthe intonations of his voice, detecting resemblances which I wondered\r\nhad never struck me before. He provoked me at times, indeed, by his\r\nevident reluctance to talk to me about his sister, though I did not\r\nquestion the friendliness of his motives in wishing to discourage my\r\nremembrance of her.\r\n\r\nHis recovery was not quite so rapid as he had expected it to be; he was\r\nnot able to mount his pony till a fortnight after the date of our\r\nreconciliation; and the first use he made of his returning strength was\r\nto ride over by night to Wildfell Hall, to see his sister. It was a\r\nhazardous enterprise both for him and for her, but he thought it\r\nnecessary to consult with her on the subject of her projected\r\ndeparture, if not to calm her apprehensions respecting his health, and\r\nthe worst result was a slight relapse of his illness, for no one knew\r\nof the visit but the inmates of the old Hall, except myself; and I\r\nbelieve it had not been his intention to mention it to me, for when I\r\ncame to see him the next day, and observed he was not so well as he\r\nought to have been, he merely said he had caught cold by being out too\r\nlate in the evening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll _never_ be able to see your sister, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t take care of\r\nyourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, a little provoked at the circumstance on her\r\naccount, instead of commiserating him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve seen her already,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve seen her!\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d And then he told me what considerations had impelled him to make\r\nthe venture, and with what precautions he had made it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how was she?\xe2\x80\x9d I eagerly asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs usual,\xe2\x80\x9d was the brief though sad reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs usual\xe2\x80\x94that is, far from happy and far from strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not positively ill,\xe2\x80\x9d returned he; \xe2\x80\x9cand she will recover her\r\nspirits in a while, I have no doubt\xe2\x80\x94but so many trials have been almost\r\ntoo much for her. How threatening those clouds look,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he,\r\nturning towards the window. \xe2\x80\x9cWe shall have thunder-showers before\r\nnight, I imagine, and they are just in the midst of stacking my corn.\r\nHave you got yours all in yet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. And, Lawrence, did she\xe2\x80\x94did your sister mention me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe asked if I had seen you lately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what else did she say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you all she said,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, with a slight smile; \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nwe talked a good deal, though my stay was but short; but our\r\nconversation was chiefly on the subject of her intended departure,\r\nwhich I begged her to delay till I was better able to assist her in her\r\nsearch after another home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut did she say no more about me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did not say much about you, Markham. I should not have encouraged\r\nher to do so, had she been inclined; but happily she was not: she only\r\nasked a few questions concerning you, and seemed satisfied with my\r\nbrief answers, wherein she showed herself wiser than her friend; and I\r\nmay tell you, too, that she seemed to be far more anxious lest you\r\nshould think too much of her, than lest you should forget her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I fear _your_ anxiety is quite the other way respecting her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is not: I wish her to be happy; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish her to forget\r\nme altogether. She knows it is impossible that I should forget _her;_\r\nand she is right to wish me not to remember her too well. I should not\r\ndesire her to regret me _too_ deeply; but I can scarcely imagine she\r\nwill make herself very unhappy about me, because I know I am not worthy\r\nof it, except in my appreciation of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are neither of you worthy of a broken heart,\xe2\x80\x94nor of all the sighs,\r\nand tears, and sorrowful thoughts that have been, and I fear will be,\r\nwasted upon you both; but, at present, each has a more exalted opinion\r\nof the other than, I fear, he or she deserves; and my sister\xe2\x80\x99s feelings\r\nare naturally full as keen as yours, and I believe _more_ constant; but\r\nshe has the good sense and fortitude to strive against them in this\r\nparticular; and I trust she will not rest till she has entirely weaned\r\nher thoughts\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom me,\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I wish you would make the like exertions,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she _tell_ you that that was her intention?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; the question was not broached between us: there was no necessity\r\nfor it, for I had no doubt that such was her determination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo forget me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Markham! Why not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well!\xe2\x80\x9d was my only audible reply; but I internally answered,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\r\nLawrence, you\xe2\x80\x99re wrong there: she is _not_ determined to forget me. It\r\nwould be _wrong_ to forget one so deeply and fondly devoted to her, who\r\ncan so thoroughly appreciate her excellencies, and sympathise with all\r\nher thoughts, as I can do, and it would be wrong in me to forget so\r\nexcellent and divine a piece of God\xe2\x80\x99s creation as she, when I have once\r\nso truly loved and known her.\xe2\x80\x9d But I said no more to him on that\r\nsubject. I instantly started a new topic of conversation, and soon took\r\nleave of my companion, with a feeling of less cordiality towards him\r\nthan usual. Perhaps I had no right to be annoyed at him, but I was so\r\nnevertheless.\r\n\r\nIn little more than a week after this I met him returning from a visit\r\nto the Wilsons\xe2\x80\x99; and I now resolved to do _him_ a good turn, though at\r\nthe expense of his feelings, and perhaps at the risk of incurring that\r\ndispleasure which is so commonly the reward of those who give\r\ndisagreeable information, or tender their advice unasked. In this,\r\nbelieve me, I was actuated by no motives of revenge for the occasional\r\nannoyances I had lately sustained from him,\xe2\x80\x94nor yet by any feeling of\r\nmalevolent enmity towards Miss Wilson, but purely by the fact that I\r\ncould not endure that such a woman should be Mrs. Huntingdon\xe2\x80\x99s sister,\r\nand that, as well for his own sake as for hers, I could not bear to\r\nthink of his being deceived into a union with one so unworthy of him,\r\nand so utterly unfitted to be the partner of his quiet home, and the\r\ncompanion of his life. He had had uncomfortable suspicions on that head\r\nhimself, I imagined; but such was his inexperience, and such were the\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s powers of attraction, and her skill in bringing them to bear\r\nupon his young imagination, that they had not disturbed him long; and I\r\nbelieve the only effectual causes of the vacillating indecision that\r\nhad preserved him hitherto from making an actual declaration of love,\r\nwas the consideration of her connections, and especially of her mother,\r\nwhom he could not abide. Had they lived at a distance, he might have\r\nsurmounted the objection, but within two or three miles of Woodford it\r\nwas really no light matter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been to call on the Wilsons, Lawrence,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, as I walked\r\nbeside his pony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, slightly averting his face: \xe2\x80\x9cI thought it but civil\r\nto take the first opportunity of returning their kind attentions, since\r\nthey have been so very particular and constant in their inquiries\r\nthroughout the whole course of my illness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all Miss Wilson\xe2\x80\x99s doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if it is,\xe2\x80\x9d returned he, with a very perceptible blush, \xe2\x80\x9cis that\r\nany reason why I should not make a suitable acknowledgment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a reason why you should not make the acknowledgment she looks\r\nfor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us drop that subject if you please,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in evident\r\ndispleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Lawrence, with your leave we\xe2\x80\x99ll continue it a while longer; and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you something, now we\xe2\x80\x99re about it, which you may believe or\r\nnot as you choose\xe2\x80\x94only please to remember that it is not my custom to\r\nspeak falsely, and that in this case I can have no motive for\r\nmisrepresenting the truth\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Markham, what now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Miss Wilson hates your sister._ It may be natural enough that, in her\r\nignorance of the relationship, she should feel some degree of enmity\r\nagainst her, but no good or amiable woman would be capable of evincing\r\nthat bitter, cold-blooded, designing malice towards a fancied rival\r\nthat I have observed in her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarkham!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94and it is my belief that Eliza Millward and she, if not the very\r\noriginators of the slanderous reports that have been propagated, were\r\ndesignedly the encouragers and chief disseminators of them. She was not\r\ndesirous to mix up _your_ name in the matter, of course, but her\r\ndelight was, and still is, to blacken your sister\xe2\x80\x99s character to the\r\nutmost of her power, without risking too greatly the exposure of her\r\nown malevolence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted my companion, his face burning with\r\nindignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, as I cannot prove it, I must content myself with asserting that\r\nit is so to the best of my belief; but as you would not willingly marry\r\nMiss Wilson if it _were_ so, you will do well to be cautious, till you\r\nhave proved it to be otherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never told you, Markham, that I _intended_ to marry Miss Wilson,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, proudly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but whether you do or not, she intends to marry you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she tell you so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have no right to make such an assertion respecting her.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nslightly quickened his pony\xe2\x80\x99s pace, but I laid my hand on its mane,\r\ndetermined he should not leave me yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a moment, Lawrence, and let me explain myself; and don\xe2\x80\x99t be so\r\nvery\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to call it\xe2\x80\x94_inaccessible_ as you are.\xe2\x80\x94I know\r\nwhat you think of Jane Wilson; and I believe I know how far you are\r\nmistaken in your opinion: you think she is singularly charming,\r\nelegant, sensible, and refined: you are not aware that she is selfish,\r\ncold-hearted, ambitious, artful, shallow-minded\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, Markham\xe2\x80\x94enough!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; let me finish:\xe2\x80\x94you don\xe2\x80\x99t know that, if you married her, your home\r\nwould be rayless and comfortless; and it would break your heart at last\r\nto find yourself united to one so wholly incapable of sharing your\r\ntastes, feelings, and ideas\xe2\x80\x94so utterly destitute of sensibility, good\r\nfeeling, and true nobility of soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you done?\xe2\x80\x9d asked my companion quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes;\xe2\x80\x94I know you hate me for my impertinence, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t care if it\r\nonly conduces to preserve you from that fatal mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d returned he, with a rather wintry smile\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad you have\r\novercome or forgotten your own afflictions so far as to be able to\r\nstudy so deeply the affairs of others, and trouble your head so\r\nunnecessarily about the fancied or possible calamities of their future\r\nlife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe parted\xe2\x80\x94somewhat coldly again: but still we did not cease to be\r\nfriends; and my well-meant warning, though it might have been more\r\njudiciously delivered, as well as more thankfully received, was not\r\nwholly unproductive of the desired effect: his visit to the Wilsons was\r\nnot repeated, and though, in our subsequent interviews, he never\r\nmentioned her name to me, nor I to him,\xe2\x80\x94I have reason to believe he\r\npondered my words in his mind, eagerly though covertly sought\r\ninformation respecting the fair lady from other quarters, secretly\r\ncompared my character of her with what he had himself observed and what\r\nhe heard from others, and finally came to the conclusion that, all\r\nthings considered, she had much better remain Miss Wilson of Ryecote\r\nFarm than be transmuted into Mrs. Lawrence of Woodford Hall. I believe,\r\ntoo, that he soon learned to contemplate with secret amazement his\r\nformer predilection, and to congratulate himself on the lucky escape he\r\nhad made; but he never confessed it to me, or hinted one word of\r\nacknowledgment for the part I had had in his deliverance, but this was\r\nnot surprising to any one that knew him as I did.\r\n\r\nAs for Jane Wilson, she, of course, was disappointed and embittered by\r\nthe sudden cold neglect and ultimate desertion of her former admirer.\r\nHad I done wrong to blight her cherished hopes? I think not; and\r\ncertainly my conscience has never accused me, from that day to this, of\r\nany evil design in the matter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLVII\r\n\r\n\r\nOne morning, about the beginning of November, while I was inditing some\r\nbusiness letters, shortly after breakfast, Eliza Millward came to call\r\nupon my sister. Rose had neither the discrimination nor the virulence\r\nto regard the little demon as I did, and they still preserved their\r\nformer intimacy. At the moment of her arrival, however, there was no\r\none in the room but Fergus and myself, my mother and sister being both\r\nof them absent, \xe2\x80\x9con household cares intent\xe2\x80\x9d; but _I_ was not going to\r\nlay myself out for her amusement, whoever else might so incline: I\r\nmerely honoured her with a careless salutation and a few words of\r\ncourse, and then went on with my writing, leaving my brother to be more\r\npolite if he chose. But she wanted to tease me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pleasure it is to find you at home, Mr. Markham!\xe2\x80\x9d said she,\r\nwith a disingenuously malicious smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI so seldom see you now, for\r\nyou never come to the vicarage. Papa, is quite offended, I can tell\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x9d she added playfully, looking into my face with an impertinent\r\nlaugh, as she seated herself, half beside and half before my desk, off\r\nthe corner of the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have had a good deal to do of late,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, without looking up from\r\nmy letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you, indeed! Somebody said you had been strangely neglecting your\r\nbusiness these last few months.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomebody said wrong, for, these last two months especially, I have\r\nbeen particularly plodding and diligent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! well, there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing like active employment, I suppose, to\r\nconsole the afflicted;\xe2\x80\x94and, excuse me, Mr. Markham, but you look so\r\nvery far from well, and have been, by all accounts, so moody and\r\nthoughtful of late,\xe2\x80\x94I could almost think you have some secret care\r\npreying on your spirits. _Formerly_,\xe2\x80\x9d said she timidly, \xe2\x80\x9cI could have\r\nventured to ask you what it was, and what I could do to comfort you: I\r\ndare not do it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re very kind, Miss Eliza. When I think you can do anything to\r\ncomfort me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll make bold to tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray do!\xe2\x80\x94I suppose I mayn\xe2\x80\x99t guess what it is that troubles you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no necessity, for I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you plainly. The thing that\r\ntroubles me the most at present is a young lady sitting at my elbow,\r\nand preventing me from finishing my letter, and, thereafter, repairing\r\nto my daily business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBefore she could reply to this ungallant speech, Rose entered the room;\r\nand Miss Eliza rising to greet her, they both seated themselves near\r\nthe fire, where that idle lad Fergus was standing, leaning his shoulder\r\nagainst the corner of the chimney-piece, with his legs crossed and his\r\nhands in his breeches-pockets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Rose, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you a piece of news\xe2\x80\x94I hope you have not heard it\r\nbefore: for good, bad, or indifferent, one always likes to be the first\r\nto tell. It\xe2\x80\x99s about that sad Mrs. Graham\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush-sh-sh!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Fergus, in a tone of solemn import. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98We never\r\nmention her; her name is never heard.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d And glancing up, I caught him\r\nwith his eye askance on me, and his finger pointed to his forehead;\r\nthen, winking at the young lady with a doleful shake of the head, he\r\nwhispered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA monomania\xe2\x80\x94but don\xe2\x80\x99t mention it\xe2\x80\x94all right but that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should be sorry to injure any one\xe2\x80\x99s feelings,\xe2\x80\x9d returned she,\r\nspeaking below her breath. \xe2\x80\x9cAnother time, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak out, Miss Eliza!\xe2\x80\x9d said I, not deigning to notice the other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbuffooneries: \xe2\x80\x9cyou needn\xe2\x80\x99t fear to say anything in my presence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d answered she, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps you know already that Mrs. Graham\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhusband is not really dead, and that she had run away from him?\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nstarted, and felt my face glow; but I bent it over my letter, and went\r\non folding it up as she proceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cBut perhaps you did _not_ know that\r\nshe is now gone back to him again, and that a perfect reconciliation\r\nhas taken place between them? Only think,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, turning to\r\nthe confounded Rose, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a fool the man must be!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who gave you this piece of intelligence, Miss Eliza?\xe2\x80\x9d said I,\r\ninterrupting my sister\xe2\x80\x99s exclamations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had it from a very authentic source.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whom, may I ask?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom one of the servants at Woodford.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I was not aware that you were on such intimate terms with Mr.\r\nLawrence\xe2\x80\x99s household.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not from the man himself that I heard it, but he told it in\r\nconfidence to our maid Sarah, and Sarah told it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn confidence, I suppose? And you tell it in confidence to us? But _I_\r\ncan tell _you_ that it is but a lame story after all, and scarcely\r\none-half of it true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile I spoke I completed the sealing and direction of my letters, with\r\na somewhat unsteady hand, in spite of all my efforts to retain\r\ncomposure, and in spite of my firm conviction that the story _was_ a\r\nlame one\xe2\x80\x94that the supposed Mrs. Graham, most certainly, had not\r\n_voluntarily_ gone back to her husband, or dreamt of a reconciliation.\r\nMost likely she was gone away, and the tale-bearing servant, not\r\nknowing what was become of her, had _conjectured_ that such was the\r\ncase, and our fair visitor had detailed it as a certainty, delighted\r\nwith such an opportunity of tormenting me. But it was possible\xe2\x80\x94barely\r\npossible\xe2\x80\x94that some one might have betrayed her, and she had been taken\r\naway by force. Determined to know the worst, I hastily pocketed my two\r\nletters, and muttered something about being too late for the post, left\r\nthe room, rushed into the yard, and vociferously called for my horse.\r\nNo one being there, I dragged him out of the stable myself, strapped\r\nthe saddle on to his back and the bridle on to his head, mounted, and\r\nspeedily galloped away to Woodford. I found its owner pensively\r\nstrolling in the grounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your sister gone?\xe2\x80\x9d were my first words as I grasped his hand,\r\ninstead of the usual inquiry after his health.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she\xe2\x80\x99s gone,\xe2\x80\x9d was his answer, so calmly spoken that my terror was\r\nat once removed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose I mayn\xe2\x80\x99t know where she is?\xe2\x80\x9d said I, as I dismounted, and\r\nrelinquished my horse to the gardener, who, being the only servant\r\nwithin call, had been summoned by his master, from his employment of\r\nraking up the dead leaves on the lawn, to take him to the stables.\r\n\r\nMy companion gravely took my arm, and leading me away to the garden,\r\nthus answered my question,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cShe is at Grassdale Manor, in \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, with a convulsive start.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Grassdale Manor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it?\xe2\x80\x9d I gasped. \xe2\x80\x9cWho betrayed her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe went of her own accord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible, Lawrence! She _could_ not be so frantic!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed I,\r\nvehemently grasping his arm, as if to force him to unsay those hateful\r\nwords.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did,\xe2\x80\x9d persisted he in the same grave, collected manner as before;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand not without reason,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, gently disengaging himself from\r\nmy grasp. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Huntingdon is ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so she went to nurse him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFool!\xe2\x80\x9d I could not help exclaiming, and Lawrence looked up with a\r\nrather reproachful glance. \xe2\x80\x9cIs he dying, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not, Markham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how many more nurses has he? How many ladies are there besides to\r\ntake care of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone; he was alone, or she would not have gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, confound it! This is intolerable!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is? That he should be alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI attempted no reply, for I was not sure that this circumstance did not\r\npartly conduce to my distraction. I therefore continued to pace the\r\nwalk in silent anguish, with my hand pressed to my forehead; then\r\nsuddenly pausing and turning to my companion, I impatiently exclaimed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did she take this infatuated step? What fiend persuaded her to\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing persuaded her but her own sense of duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumbug!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was half inclined to say so myself, Markham, at first. I assure you\r\nit was not by my advice that she went, for I detest that man as\r\nfervently as you can do,\xe2\x80\x94except, indeed, that his reformation would\r\ngive me much greater pleasure than his death; but all I did was to\r\ninform her of the circumstance of his illness (the consequence of a\r\nfall from his horse in hunting), and to tell her that that unhappy\r\nperson, Miss Myers, had left him some time ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was ill done! Now, when he finds the convenience of her presence,\r\nhe will make all manner of lying speeches and false, fair promises for\r\nthe future, and she will believe him, and then her condition will be\r\nten times worse and ten times more irremediable than before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere does not appear to be much ground for such apprehensions at\r\npresent,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, producing a letter from his pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom the\r\naccount I received this morning, I should say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was _her_ writing! By an irresistible impulse I held out my hand,\r\nand the words, \xe2\x80\x9cLet me see it,\xe2\x80\x9d involuntarily passed my lips. He was\r\nevidently reluctant to grant the request, but while he hesitated I\r\nsnatched it from his hand. Recollecting myself, however, the minute\r\nafter, I offered to restore it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, take it,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cif you don\xe2\x80\x99t want me to read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may read it if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI read it, and so may you.\r\n\r\nGrassdale, Nov. 4th.\r\n\r\n\r\nDEAR FREDERICK,\xe2\x80\x94I know you will be anxious to hear from me, and I will\r\ntell you all I can. Mr. Huntingdon is very ill, but not dying, or in\r\nany immediate danger; and he is rather better at present than he was\r\nwhen I came. I found the house in sad confusion: Mrs. Greaves, Benson,\r\nevery decent servant had left, and those that were come to supply their\r\nplaces were a negligent, disorderly set, to say no worse\xe2\x80\x94I must change\r\nthem again, if I stay. A professional nurse, a grim, hard old woman,\r\nhad been hired to attend the wretched invalid. He suffers much, and has\r\nno fortitude to bear him through. The immediate injuries he sustained\r\nfrom the accident, however, were not very severe, and would, as the\r\ndoctor says, have been but trifling to a man of temperate habits, but\r\nwith _him_ it is very different. On the night of my arrival, when I\r\nfirst entered his room, he was lying in a kind of half delirium. He did\r\nnot notice me till I spoke, and then he mistook me for another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it you, Alice, come again?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you leave me\r\nfor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is I, Arthur\xe2\x80\x94it is Helen, your wife,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a start. \xe2\x80\x9cFor heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t mention\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94I have none. Devil take her,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, a moment after, \xe2\x80\x9cand you,\r\ntoo! What did you do it for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said no more; but observing that he kept gazing towards the foot of\r\nthe bed, I went and sat there, placing the light so as to shine full\r\nupon me, for I thought he might be dying, and I wanted him to know me.\r\nFor a long time he lay silently looking upon me, first with a vacant\r\nstare, then with a fixed gaze of strange growing intensity. At last he\r\nstartled me by suddenly raising himself on his elbow and demanding in a\r\nhorrified whisper, with his eyes still fixed upon me, \xe2\x80\x9cWho is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Helen Huntingdon,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, quietly rising at the same time, and\r\nremoving to a less conspicuous position.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must be going mad,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cor something\xe2\x80\x94delirious, perhaps; but\r\nleave me, whoever you are. I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear that white face, and those\r\neyes. For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake go, and send me somebody else that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t look\r\nlike that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI went at once, and sent the hired nurse; but next morning I ventured\r\nto enter his chamber again, and, taking the nurse\xe2\x80\x99s place by his\r\nbedside, I watched him and waited on him for several hours, showing\r\nmyself as little as possible, and only speaking when necessary, and\r\nthen not above my breath. At first he addressed me as the nurse, but,\r\non my crossing the room to draw up the window-blinds, in obedience to\r\nhis directions, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t nurse; it\xe2\x80\x99s Alice. Stay with me,\r\ndo! That old hag will be the death of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to stay with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. And after that he would call me\r\nAlice, or some other name almost equally repugnant to my feelings. I\r\nforced myself to endure it for a while, fearing a contradiction might\r\ndisturb him too much; but when, having asked for a glass of water,\r\nwhile I held it to his lips, he murmured, \xe2\x80\x9cThanks, dearest!\xe2\x80\x9d I could\r\nnot help distinctly observing, \xe2\x80\x9cYou would not say so if you knew me,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nintending to follow that up with another declaration of my identity;\r\nbut he merely muttered an incoherent reply, so I dropped it again, till\r\nsome time after, when, as I was bathing his forehead and temples with\r\nvinegar and water to relieve the heat and pain in his head, he\r\nobserved, after looking earnestly upon me for some minutes, \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nsuch strange fancies\xe2\x80\x94I can\xe2\x80\x99t get rid of them, and they won\xe2\x80\x99t let me\r\nrest; and the most singular and pertinacious of them all is your face\r\nand voice\xe2\x80\x94they seem just like hers. I could swear at this moment that\r\nshe was by my side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is,\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat seems comfortable,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, without noticing my words; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nwhile you do it, the other fancies fade away\xe2\x80\x94but _this_ only\r\nstrengthens.\xe2\x80\x94Go on\xe2\x80\x94go on, till it vanishes, too. I can\xe2\x80\x99t stand such a\r\nmania as this; it would kill me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt never will vanish,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, distinctly, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is the truth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, starting, as if an asp had stung him. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmean to say that you are really she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do; but you needn\xe2\x80\x99t shrink away from me, as if I were your greatest\r\nenemy: I am come to take care of you, and do what none of _them_ would\r\ndo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t torment me now!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he in pitiable agitation;\r\nand then he began to mutter bitter curses against me, or the evil\r\nfortune that had brought me there; while I put down the sponge and\r\nbasin, and resumed my seat at the bed-side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are they?\xe2\x80\x9d said he: \xe2\x80\x9chave they all left me\xe2\x80\x94servants and all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are servants within call if you want them; but you had better\r\nlie down now and be quiet: none of them could or would attend you as\r\ncarefully as I shall do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t understand it at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in bewildered perplexity. \xe2\x80\x9cWas\r\nit a dream that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and he covered his eyes with his hands, as if trying\r\nto unravel the mystery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Arthur, it was not a dream, that your conduct was such as to\r\noblige me to leave you; but I heard that you were ill and alone, and I\r\nam come back to nurse you. You need not fear to trust me: tell me all\r\nyour wants, and I will try to satisfy them. There is no one else to\r\ncare for you; and I shall not upbraid you now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I see,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a bitter smile; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s an act of Christian\r\ncharity, whereby you hope to gain a higher seat in heaven for yourself,\r\nand scoop a deeper pit in hell for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I came to offer you that comfort and assistance your situation\r\nrequired; and if I could benefit your soul as well as your body, and\r\nawaken some sense of contrition and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; if you could overwhelm me with remorse and confusion of face,\r\nnow\xe2\x80\x99s the time. What have you done with my son?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is well, and you may see him some time, if you will compose\r\nyourself, but not now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is safe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWherever he is, you will not see him till you have promised to leave\r\nhim entirely under my care and protection, and to let me take him away\r\nwhenever and wherever I please, if I should hereafter judge it\r\nnecessary to remove him again. But we will talk of that to-morrow: you\r\nmust be quiet now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, let me see him now, I promise, if it _must_ be so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear it, as God is in Heaven! Now, then, let me see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I cannot trust your oaths and promises: I must have a written\r\nagreement, and you must sign it in presence of a witness: but not\r\nto-day\xe2\x80\x94to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, to-day; now,\xe2\x80\x9d persisted he: and he was in such a state of feverish\r\nexcitement, and so bent upon the immediate gratification of his wish,\r\nthat I thought it better to grant it at once, as I saw he would not\r\nrest till I did. But I was determined my son\xe2\x80\x99s interest should not be\r\nforgotten; and having clearly written out the promise I wished Mr.\r\nHuntingdon to give upon a slip of paper, I deliberately read it over to\r\nhim, and made him sign it in the presence of Rachel. He begged I would\r\nnot insist upon this: it was a useless exposure of my want of faith in\r\nhis word to the servant. I told him I was sorry, but since he had\r\nforfeited my confidence, he must take the consequence. He next pleaded\r\ninability to hold the pen. \xe2\x80\x9cThen we must wait until you can hold it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid I. Upon which he said he would try; but then he could not see to\r\nwrite. I placed my finger where the signature was to be, and told him\r\nhe might write his name in the dark, if he only knew where to put it.\r\nBut he had not power to form the letters. \xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, you must be\r\ntoo ill to see the child,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; and finding me inexorable, he at\r\nlength managed to ratify the agreement; and I bade Rachel send the boy.\r\n\r\nAll this may strike you as harsh, but I felt I must not lose my present\r\nadvantage, and my son\xe2\x80\x99s future welfare should not be sacrificed to any\r\nmistaken tenderness for this man\xe2\x80\x99s feelings. Little Arthur had not\r\nforgotten his father, but thirteen months of absence, during which he\r\nhad seldom been permitted to hear a word about him, or hardly to\r\nwhisper his name, had rendered him somewhat shy; and when he was\r\nushered into the darkened room where the sick man lay, so altered from\r\nhis former self, with fiercely flushed face and wildly-gleaming eyes\xe2\x80\x94he\r\ninstinctively clung to me, and stood looking on his father with a\r\ncountenance expressive of far more awe than pleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here, Arthur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, extending his hand towards him.\r\nThe child went, and timidly touched that burning hand, but almost\r\nstarted in alarm, when his father suddenly clutched his arm and drew\r\nhim nearer to his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Huntingdon, intently perusing his features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho am I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you glad to see me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re _not!_\xe2\x80\x9d replied the disappointed parent, relaxing his hold, and\r\ndarting a vindictive glance at me.\r\n\r\nArthur, thus released, crept back to me and put his hand in mine. His\r\nfather swore I had made the child hate him, and abused and cursed me\r\nbitterly. The instant he began I sent our son out of the room; and when\r\nhe paused to breathe, I calmly assured him that he was entirely\r\nmistaken; I had never once attempted to prejudice his child against\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did indeed desire him to _forget_ you,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cand especially to\r\nforget the lessons you taught him; and for that cause, and to lessen\r\nthe danger of discovery, I own I have generally discouraged his\r\ninclination to talk about you; but no one can blame me for that, I\r\nthink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe invalid only replied by groaning aloud, and rolling his head on a\r\npillow in a paroxysm of impatience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am in hell, already!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cThis cursed thirst is burning my\r\nheart to ashes! Will _nobody_\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBefore he could finish the sentence I had poured out a glass of some\r\nacidulated, cooling drink that was on the table, and brought it to him.\r\nHe drank it greedily, but muttered, as I took away the glass,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nsuppose you\xe2\x80\x99re heaping coals of fire on my head, you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot noticing this speech, I asked if there was anything else I could do\r\nfor him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you another opportunity of showing your Christian\r\nmagnanimity,\xe2\x80\x9d sneered he: \xe2\x80\x9cset my pillow straight, and these confounded\r\nbed-clothes.\xe2\x80\x9d I did so. \xe2\x80\x9cThere: now get me another glass of that slop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nI complied. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is delightful, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said he with a malicious\r\ngrin, as I held it to his lips; \xe2\x80\x9cyou never hoped for such a glorious\r\nopportunity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, shall I stay with you?\xe2\x80\x9d said I, as I replaced the glass on the\r\ntable: \xe2\x80\x9cor will you be more quiet if I go and send the nurse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, you\xe2\x80\x99re wondrous gentle and obliging! But you\xe2\x80\x99ve driven me mad\r\nwith it all!\xe2\x80\x9d responded he, with an impatient toss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll leave you, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; and I withdrew, and did not trouble him\r\nwith my presence again that day, except for a minute or two at a time,\r\njust to see how he was and what he wanted.\r\n\r\nNext morning the doctor ordered him to be bled; and after that he was\r\nmore subdued and tranquil. I passed half the day in his room at\r\ndifferent intervals. My presence did not appear to agitate or irritate\r\nhim as before, and he accepted my services quietly, without any bitter\r\nremarks: indeed, he scarcely spoke at all, except to make known his\r\nwants, and hardly then. But on the morrow, that is to say, in\r\nproportion as he recovered from the state of exhaustion and\r\nstupefaction, his ill-nature appeared to revive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, this sweet revenge!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, when I had been doing all I could\r\nto make him comfortable and to remedy the carelessness of his nurse.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you can enjoy it with such a quiet conscience too, because it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall in the way of duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well for me that I _am_ doing my duty,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, with a\r\nbitterness I could not repress, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is the only comfort I have; and\r\nthe satisfaction of my own conscience, it seems, is the only reward I\r\nneed look for!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked rather surprised at the earnestness of my manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat reward _did_ you look for?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will think me a liar if I tell you; but I _did_ hope to benefit\r\nyou: as well to better your mind as to alleviate your present\r\nsufferings; but it appears I am to do neither; your own bad spirit will\r\nnot let me. As far as _you_ are concerned, I have sacrificed my own\r\nfeelings, and all the little earthly comfort that was left me, to no\r\npurpose; and every little thing I do for you is ascribed to\r\nself-righteous malice and refined revenge!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all very fine, I daresay,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, eyeing me with stupid\r\namazement; \xe2\x80\x9cand of course I ought to be melted to tears of penitence\r\nand admiration at the sight of so much generosity and superhuman\r\ngoodness; but you see I can\xe2\x80\x99t manage it. However, pray do me all the\r\ngood you can, if you do really find any pleasure in it; for you\r\nperceive I am almost as miserable just now as you need wish to see me.\r\nSince you came, I confess, I have had better attendance than before,\r\nfor these wretches neglected me shamefully, and all my old friends seem\r\nto have fairly forsaken me. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had a dreadful time of it, I assure\r\nyou: I sometimes thought I should have died: do you think there\xe2\x80\x99s any\r\nchance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s always a chance of death; and it is always well to live with\r\nsuch a chance in view.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! but do you think there\xe2\x80\x99s any likelihood that this illness\r\nwill have a fatal termination?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell; but, supposing it should, how are you prepared to meet\r\nthe event?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the doctor told me I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to think about it, for I was sure to\r\nget better if I stuck to his regimen and prescriptions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you may, Arthur; but neither the doctor nor I can speak with\r\ncertainty in such a case; there is internal injury, and it is difficult\r\nto know to what extent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now! you want to scare me to death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to lull you to false security. If a consciousness\r\nof the uncertainty of life can dispose you to serious and useful\r\nthoughts, I would not deprive you of the benefit of such reflections,\r\nwhether you do eventually recover or not. Does the idea of death appal\r\nyou very much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just the only thing I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to think of; so if you\xe2\x80\x99ve any\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it must come some time,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted I, \xe2\x80\x9cand if it be years hence,\r\nit will as certainly overtake you as if it came to-day,\xe2\x80\x94and no doubt be\r\nas unwelcome then as now, unless you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, hang it! don\xe2\x80\x99t torment me with your preachments now, unless you\r\nwant to kill me outright. I can\xe2\x80\x99t stand it, I tell you. I\xe2\x80\x99ve sufferings\r\nenough without that. If you think there\xe2\x80\x99s danger, save me from it; and\r\nthen, in gratitude, I\xe2\x80\x99ll hear whatever you like to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI accordingly dropped the unwelcome topic. And now, Frederick, I think\r\nI may bring my letter to a close. From these details you may form your\r\nown judgment of the state of my patient, and of my own position and\r\nfuture prospects. Let me hear from you soon, and I will write again to\r\ntell you how we get on; but now that my presence is tolerated, and even\r\nrequired, in the sick-room, I shall have but little time to spare\r\nbetween my husband and my son,\xe2\x80\x94for I must not entirely neglect the\r\nlatter: it would not do to keep him always with Rachel, and I dare not\r\nleave him for a moment with any of the other servants, or suffer him to\r\nbe alone, lest he should meet them. If his father get worse, I shall\r\nask Esther Hargrave to take charge of him for a time, till I have\r\nreorganised the household at least; but I greatly prefer keeping him\r\nunder my own eye.\r\n\r\nI find myself in rather a singular position: I am exerting my utmost\r\nendeavours to promote the recovery and reformation of my husband, and\r\nif I succeed, what shall I do? My duty, of course,\xe2\x80\x94but how? No matter;\r\nI can perform the task that is before me now, and God will give me\r\nstrength to do whatever He requires hereafter. Good-by, dear Frederick.\r\n\r\nHELEN HUNTINGDON.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lawrence, as I silently refolded the\r\nletter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d returned I, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she is casting her pearls before\r\nswine. May they be satisfied with trampling them under their feet, and\r\nnot turn again and rend her! But I shall say no more against her: I see\r\nthat she was actuated by the best and noblest motives in what she has\r\ndone; and if the act is not a wise one, may heaven protect her from its\r\nconsequences! May I keep this letter, Lawrence?\xe2\x80\x94you see she has never\r\nonce mentioned me throughout\xe2\x80\x94or made the most distant allusion to me;\r\ntherefore, there can be no impropriety or harm in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, therefore, why should you wish to keep it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere not these characters written by her hand? and were not these\r\nwords conceived in her mind, and many of them spoken by her lips?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. And so I kept it; otherwise, Halford, you could never\r\nhave become so thoroughly acquainted with its contents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when you write,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you have the goodness to ask her if\r\nI may be permitted to enlighten my mother and sister on her real\r\nhistory and circumstance, just so far as is necessary to make the\r\nneighbourhood sensible of the shameful injustice they have done her? I\r\nwant no tender messages, but just ask her that, and tell her it is the\r\ngreatest favour she could do me; and tell her\xe2\x80\x94no, nothing more. You see\r\nI know the address, and I might write to her myself, but I am so\r\nvirtuous as to refrain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll do this for you, Markham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as soon as you receive an answer, you\xe2\x80\x99ll let me know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf all be well, I\xe2\x80\x99ll come myself and tell you immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER XLVIII\r\n\r\n\r\nFive or six days after this Mr. Lawrence paid us the honour of a call;\r\nand when he and I were alone together\xe2\x80\x94which I contrived as soon as\r\npossible by bringing him out to look at my cornstacks\xe2\x80\x94he showed me\r\nanother letter from his sister. This one he was quite willing to submit\r\nto my longing gaze; he thought, I suppose, it would do me good. The\r\nonly answer it gave to my message was this:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Markham is at liberty to make such revelations concerning me as he\r\njudges necessary. He will know that I should wish but little to be said\r\non the subject. I hope he is well; but tell him he must not think of\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI can give you a few extracts from the rest of the letter, for I was\r\npermitted to keep this also\xe2\x80\x94perhaps, as an antidote to all pernicious\r\nhopes and fancies.\r\n\r\n* * * * *\r\n\r\n\r\nHe is decidedly better, but very low from the depressing effects of his\r\nsevere illness and the strict regimen he is obliged to observe\xe2\x80\x94so\r\nopposite to all his previous habits. It is deplorable to see how\r\ncompletely his past life has degenerated his once noble constitution,\r\nand vitiated the whole system of his organization. But the doctor says\r\nhe may now be considered out of danger, if he will only continue to\r\nobserve the necessary restrictions.
