I stood beside the carriage, and, the\r\nwindow being down, I saw my happy friend fondly encircle his\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s waist with his arm, while she rested her glowing cheek on\r\nhis shoulder, looking the very impersonation of loving, trusting bliss.\r\nIn the interval between the footman\xe2\x80\x99s closing the door and taking his\r\nplace behind she raised her smiling brown eyes to his face, observing,\r\nplayfully,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI fear you must think me very insensible, Frederick: I know\r\nit is the custom for ladies to cry on these occasions, but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsqueeze a tear for my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe only answered with a kiss, and pressed her still closer to his\r\nbosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is this?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Esther, you\xe2\x80\x99re crying now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s only too much happiness\xe2\x80\x94and the wish,\xe2\x80\x9d sobbed\r\nshe, \xe2\x80\x9cthat our dear Helen were as happy as ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless you for that wish!\xe2\x80\x9d I inwardly responded, as the carriage rolled\r\naway\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand heaven grant it be not wholly vain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought a cloud had suddenly darkened her husband\xe2\x80\x99s face as she\r\nspoke. What did he think? Could he grudge such happiness to his dear\r\nsister and his friend as he now felt himself? At _such_ a moment it was\r\nimpossible. The contrast between her fate and his _must_ darken his\r\nbliss for a time. Perhaps, too, he thought of me: perhaps he regretted\r\nthe part he had had in preventing our union, by omitting to help us, if\r\nnot by actually plotting against us. I exonerated him from _that_\r\ncharge now, and deeply lamented my former ungenerous suspicions; but he\r\n_had_ wronged us, still\xe2\x80\x94I hoped, I trusted that he had. He had not\r\nattempted to check the course of our love by actually damming up the\r\nstreams in their passage, but he had passively watched the two currents\r\nwandering through life\xe2\x80\x99s arid wilderness, declining to clear away the\r\nobstructions that divided them, and secretly hoping that both would\r\nlose themselves in the sand before they could be joined in one. And\r\nmeantime he had been quietly proceeding with his own affairs; perhaps,\r\nhis heart and head had been so full of his fair lady that he had had\r\nbut little thought to spare for others. Doubtless he had made his first\r\nacquaintance with her\xe2\x80\x94his first intimate acquaintance at least\xe2\x80\x94during\r\nhis three months\xe2\x80\x99 sojourn at F\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, for I now recollected that he had\r\nonce casually let fall an intimation that his aunt and sister had a\r\nyoung friend staying with them at the time, and this accounted for at\r\nleast one-half his silence about all transactions there. Now, too, I\r\nsaw a reason for many little things that had slightly puzzled me\r\nbefore; among the rest, for sundry departures from Woodford, and\r\nabsences more or less prolonged, for which he never satisfactorily\r\naccounted, and concerning which he hated to be questioned on his\r\nreturn. Well might the servant say his master was \xe2\x80\x9cvery close.\xe2\x80\x9d But why\r\nthis strange reserve to _me?_ Partly, from that remarkable idiosyncrasy\r\nto which I have before alluded; partly, perhaps, from tenderness to my\r\nfeelings, or fear to disturb my philosophy by touching upon the\r\ninfectious theme of love.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER LII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe tardy gig had overtaken me at last. I entered it, and bade the man\r\nwho brought it drive to Grassdale Manor\xe2\x80\x94I was too busy with my own\r\nthoughts to care to drive it myself. I would see Mrs. Huntingdon\xe2\x80\x94there\r\ncould be no impropriety in that now that her husband had been dead\r\nabove a year\xe2\x80\x94and by her indifference or her joy at my unexpected\r\narrival I could soon tell whether her heart was truly mine. But my\r\ncompanion, a loquacious, forward fellow, was not disposed to leave me\r\nto the indulgence of my private cogitations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere they go!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as the carriages filed away before us.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99ll be brave doings on yonder _to-day_, as what come\r\nto-morra.\xe2\x80\x94Know anything of that family, sir? or you\xe2\x80\x99re a stranger in\r\nthese parts?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know them by report.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph! There\xe2\x80\x99s the best of \xe2\x80\x99em gone, anyhow. And I suppose the old\r\nmissis is agoing to leave after this stir\xe2\x80\x99s gotten overed, and take\r\nherself off, somewhere, to live on her bit of a jointure; and the young\r\n\xe2\x80\x99un\xe2\x80\x94at least the new \xe2\x80\x99un (she\xe2\x80\x99s none so very young)\xe2\x80\x94is coming down to\r\nlive at the Grove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Hargrave married, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, sir, a few months since. He should a been wed afore, to a widow\r\nlady, but they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t agree over the money: she\xe2\x80\x99d a rare long purse,\r\nand Mr. Hargrave wanted it all to hisself; but she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let it go,\r\nand so then they fell out. This one isn\xe2\x80\x99t quite as rich, nor as\r\nhandsome either, but she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been married before. She\xe2\x80\x99s very plain,\r\nthey say, and getting on to forty or past, and so, you know, if she\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t jump at this hopportunity, she thought she\xe2\x80\x99d never get a better.\r\nI guess she thought such a handsome young husband was worth all \xe2\x80\x99at\r\never she had, and he might take it and welcome, but I lay she\xe2\x80\x99ll rue\r\nher bargain afore long. They say she begins already to see \xe2\x80\x99at he isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nnot altogether that nice, generous, perlite, delightful gentleman \xe2\x80\x99at\r\nshe thought him afore marriage\xe2\x80\x94he begins a being careless and masterful\r\nalready. Ay, and she\xe2\x80\x99ll find him harder and carelesser nor she thinks\r\non.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou seem to be well acquainted with him,\xe2\x80\x9d I observed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, sir; I\xe2\x80\x99ve known him since he was quite a young gentleman; and a\r\nproud \xe2\x80\x99un he was, and a wilful. I was servant yonder for several years;\r\nbut I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stand their niggardly ways\xe2\x80\x94she got ever longer and\r\nworse, did missis, with her nipping and screwing, and watching and\r\ngrudging; so I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d find another place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we not near the house?\xe2\x80\x9d said I, interrupting him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir; yond\xe2\x80\x99s the park.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy heart sank within me to behold that stately mansion in the midst of\r\nits expansive grounds. The park as beautiful now, in its wintry garb,\r\nas it could be in its summer glory: the majestic sweep, the undulating\r\nswell and fall, displayed to full advantage in that robe of dazzling\r\npurity, stainless and printless\xe2\x80\x94save one long, winding track left by\r\nthe trooping deer\xe2\x80\x94the stately timber-trees with their heavy-laden\r\nbranches gleaming white against the dull, grey sky; the deep,\r\nencircling woods; the broad expanse of water sleeping in frozen quiet;\r\nand the weeping ash and willow drooping their snow-clad boughs above\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94all presented a picture, striking indeed, and pleasing to an\r\nunencumbered mind, but by no means encouraging to me. There was one\r\ncomfort, however,\xe2\x80\x94all this was entailed upon little Arthur, and could\r\nnot under any circumstances, strictly speaking, be his mother\xe2\x80\x99s. But\r\nhow was she situated? Overcoming with a sudden effort my repugnance to\r\nmention her name to my garrulous companion, I asked him if he knew\r\nwhether her late husband had left a will, and how the property had been\r\ndisposed of. Oh, yes, he knew all about it; and I was quickly informed\r\nthat to her had been left the full control and management of the estate\r\nduring her son\xe2\x80\x99s minority, besides the absolute, unconditional\r\npossession of her own fortune (but I knew that her father had not given\r\nher much), and the small additional sum that had been settled upon her\r\nbefore marriage.\r\n\r\nBefore the close of the explanation we drew up at the park-gates. Now\r\nfor the trial. If I should find her within\xe2\x80\x94but alas! she might be still\r\nat Staningley: her brother had given me no intimation to the contrary.\r\nI inquired at the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge if Mrs. Huntingdon were at home. No,\r\nshe was with her aunt in \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire, but was expected to return before\r\nChristmas. She usually spent most of her time at Staningley, only\r\ncoming to Grassdale occasionally, when the management of affairs, or\r\nthe interest of her tenants and dependents, required her presence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNear what town is Staningley situated?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked. The requisite\r\ninformation was soon obtained. \xe2\x80\x9cNow then, my man, give me the reins,\r\nand we\xe2\x80\x99ll return to M\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. I must have some breakfast at the \xe2\x80\x98Rose and\r\nCrown,\xe2\x80\x99 and then away to Staningley by the first coach for \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt M\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 I had time before the coach started to replenish my forces with\r\na hearty breakfast, and to obtain the refreshment of my usual morning\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nablutions, and the amelioration of some slight change in my toilet, and\r\nalso to despatch a short note to my mother (excellent son that I was),\r\nto assure her that I was still in existence, and to excuse my\r\nnon-appearance at the expected time. It was a long journey to\r\nStaningley for those slow-travelling days, but I did not deny myself\r\nneedful refreshment on the road, nor even a night\xe2\x80\x99s rest at a wayside\r\ninn, choosing rather to brook a little delay than to present myself\r\nworn, wild, and weather-beaten before my mistress and her aunt, who\r\nwould be astonished enough to see me without that. Next morning,\r\ntherefore, I not only fortified myself with as substantial a breakfast\r\nas my excited feelings would allow me to swallow, but I bestowed a\r\nlittle more than usual time and care upon my toilet; and, furnished\r\nwith a change of linen from my small carpet-bag, well-brushed clothes,\r\nwell-polished boots, and neat new gloves, I mounted \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lightning,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand resumed my journey. I had nearly two stages yet before me, but the\r\ncoach, I was informed, passed through the neighbourhood of Staningley,\r\nand having desired to be set down as near the Hall as possible, I had\r\nnothing to do but to sit with folded arms and speculate upon the coming\r\nhour.\r\n\r\nIt was a clear, frosty morning. The very fact of sitting exalted aloft,\r\nsurveying the snowy landscape and sweet sunny sky, inhaling the pure,\r\nbracing air, and crunching away over the crisp frozen snow, was\r\nexhilarating enough in itself; but add to this the idea of to what goal\r\nI was hastening, and whom I expected to meet, and you may have some\r\nfaint conception of my frame of mind at the time\xe2\x80\x94only a _faint_ one,\r\nthough, for my heart swelled with unspeakable delight, and my spirits\r\nrose almost to madness, in spite of my prudent endeavours to bind them\r\ndown to a reasonable platitude by thinking of the undeniable difference\r\nbetween Helen\xe2\x80\x99s rank and mine; of all that she had passed through since\r\nour parting; of her long, unbroken silence; and, above all, of her\r\ncool, cautious aunt, whose counsels she would doubtless be careful not\r\nto slight again. These considerations made my heart flutter with\r\nanxiety, and my chest heave with impatience to get the crisis over; but\r\nthey could not dim her image in my mind, or mar the vivid recollection\r\nof what had been said and felt between us, or destroy the keen\r\nanticipation of what was to be: in fact, I could not realise their\r\nterrors now. Towards the close of the journey, however, a couple of my\r\nfellow-passengers kindly came to my assistance, and brought me low\r\nenough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFine land this,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of them, pointing with his umbrella to the\r\nwide fields on the right, conspicuous for their compact hedgerows,\r\ndeep, well-cut ditches, and fine timber-trees, growing sometimes on the\r\nborders, sometimes in the midst of the enclosure: \xe2\x80\x9c_very_ fine land, if\r\nyou saw it in the summer or spring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d responded the other, a gruff elderly man, with a drab greatcoat\r\nbuttoned up to the chin, and a cotton umbrella between his knees. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nold Maxwell\xe2\x80\x99s, I suppose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt _was_ his, sir; but he\xe2\x80\x99s dead now, you\xe2\x80\x99re aware, and has left it\r\nall to his niece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery rood of it, and the mansion-house and all! every hatom of his\r\nworldly goods, except just a trifle, by way of remembrance, to his\r\nnephew down in \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire, and an annuity to his wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s strange, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, sir; and she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t his own niece neither. And then his wife advised him to\r\nit, they say: she\xe2\x80\x99d brought most of the property, and it was her wish\r\nthat this lady should have it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph! Gladly\r\nwould I have lingered round the place for hours, in the hope of\r\ncatching at least one distant glimpse of her before I went, but it must\r\nnot be\xe2\x80\x94I must not suffer her to see me; for what could have brought me\r\nhither but the hope of reviving her attachment, with a view hereafter\r\nto obtain her hand? And could I bear that she should think me capable\r\nof such a thing?\xe2\x80\x94of presuming upon the acquaintance\xe2\x80\x94the _love_, if you\r\nwill\xe2\x80\x94accidentally contracted, or rather forced upon her against her\r\nwill, when she was an unknown fugitive, toiling for her own support,\r\napparently without fortune, family, or connections; to come upon her\r\nnow, when she was reinstated in her proper sphere, and claim a share in\r\nher prosperity, which, had it never failed her, would most certainly\r\nhave kept her unknown to me for ever? No! The very idea was intolerable.\r\n\r\nAnd even if she should have a lingering affection for me still, ought I\r\nto disturb her peace by awakening those feelings? to subject her to the\r\nstruggles of conflicting duty and inclination\xe2\x80\x94to whichsoever side the\r\nlatter might allure, or the former imperatively call her\xe2\x80\x94whether she\r\nshould deem it her duty to risk the slights and censures of the world,\r\nthe sorrow and displeasure of those she loved, for a romantic idea of\r\ntruth and constancy to me, or to sacrifice her individual wishes to the\r\nfeelings of her friends and her own sense of prudence and the fitness\r\nof things? Forever adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo said I\xe2\x80\x94and yet I could not tear myself away. I must not see again\xe2\x80\x94then\r\nwalked a few steps further; and then, lost in melancholy musings,\r\npaused again and leant my back against a rough old tree that grew\r\nbeside the road.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n CHAPTER LIII\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile standing thus, absorbed in my gloomy reverie, a gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncarriage came round the corner of the road. I did not look at it; and\r\nhad it rolled quietly by me, I should not have remembered the fact of\r\nits appearance at all; but a tiny voice from within it roused me by\r\nexclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cMamma, mamma, here\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Markham!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did not hear the reply, but presently the same voice answered, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nindeed, mamma\xe2\x80\x94look for yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did not raise my eyes, but I suppose mamma looked, for a clear\r\nmelodious voice, whose tones thrilled through my nerves, exclaimed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, aunt! here\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Markham, Arthur\xe2\x80\x99s friend! Go on, Richard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a touch of sadness as well as coldness in her voice, but I\r\nknew not to what to ascribe it. The carriage drove on and entered the\r\ngates before us. Arrived at the hall-door, I paused on the steps\r\nand looked round me, waiting to recover my composure, if possible\xe2\x80\x94or,\r\nat any rate, to remember my new-formed resolutions and the principles\r\non which they were founded; and it was not till Arthur had been for\r\nsome time gently pulling my coat, and repeating his invitations to\r\nenter, that I at length consented to accompany him into the apartment\r\nwhere the ladies awaited us.\r\n\r\nHelen eyed me as I entered with a kind of gentle, serious scrutiny, and\r\npolitely asked after Mrs. Markham and Rose. how you all are at Lindenhope\xe2\x80\x94has nothing happened\r\nsince I left you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody dead? nobody supplanted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe dropped her voice so low in the last sentence that no one could\r\nhave caught the concluding words but myself, and at the same time\r\nturned her eyes upon me with a dawning smile, most sweetly melancholy,\r\nand a look of timid though keen inquiry that made my cheeks tingle with\r\ninexpressible emotions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe not,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered. \xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not, if others are as little\r\nchanged as I.\xe2\x80\x9d Her face glowed in sympathy with mine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you really did not mean to call?\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feared to intrude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo intrude!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, with an impatient gesture. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d but as if\r\nsuddenly recollecting her aunt\xe2\x80\x99s presence, she checked herself, and,\r\nturning to that lady, continued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, aunt, this man is my brother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclose friend, and was my own intimate acquaintance (for a few short\r\nmonths at least), and professed a great attachment to my boy\xe2\x80\x94and when\r\nhe passes the house, so many scores of miles from his home, he declines\r\nto look in for fear of intruding!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Markham is over-modest,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Mrs. Maxwell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver-ceremonious rather,\xe2\x80\x9d said her niece\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cover\xe2\x80\x94well, it\xe2\x80\x99s no matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd turning from me, she seated herself in a chair beside the table,\r\nand pulling a book to her by the cover, began to turn over the leaves\r\nin an energetic kind of abstraction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had known,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you would have honoured me by\r\nremembering me as an intimate acquaintance, I most likely should not\r\nhave denied myself the pleasure of calling upon you, but I thought you\r\nhad forgotten me long ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou judged of others by yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered she without raising her\r\neyes from the book, but reddening as she spoke, and hastily turning\r\nover a dozen leaves at once.\r\n\r\nThere was a pause, of which Arthur thought he might venture to avail\r\nhimself to introduce his handsome young setter, and show me how\r\nwonderfully it was grown and improved, and to ask after the welfare of\r\nits father Sancho. Mrs. Maxwell then withdrew to take off her things.\r\nHelen immediately pushed the book from her, and after silently\r\nsurveying her son, his friend, and his dog for a few moments, she\r\ndismissed the former from the room under pretence of wishing him to\r\nfetch his last new book to show me. The child obeyed with alacrity; but\r\nI continued caressing the dog. The silence might have lasted till its\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s return, had it depended on me to break it; but, in half a\r\nminute or less, my hostess impatiently rose, and, taking her former\r\nstation on the rug between me and the chimney corner, earnestly\r\nexclaimed\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGilbert, what _is_ the matter with you?\xe2\x80\x94why are you so changed? It is\r\na very indiscreet question, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d she hastened to add: \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps a\r\nvery rude one\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t answer it if you think so\xe2\x80\x94but I hate mysteries and\r\nconcealments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not changed, Helen\xe2\x80\x94unfortunately I am as keen and passionate as\r\never\xe2\x80\x94it is not I, it is circumstances that are changed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat circumstances? _Do_ tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d Her cheek was blanched with the\r\nvery anguish of anxiety\xe2\x80\x94could it be with the fear that I had rashly\r\npledged my faith to another?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you at once,\xe2\x80\x9d said I. \xe2\x80\x9cI will confess that I came here for\r\nthe purpose of seeing you (not without some monitory misgivings at my\r\nown presumption, and fears that I should be as little welcome as\r\nexpected when I came), but I did not know that this estate was yours\r\nuntil enlightened on the subject of your inheritance by the\r\nconversation of two fellow-passengers in the last stage of my journey;\r\nand then I saw at once the folly of the hopes I had cherished, and the\r\nmadness of retaining them a moment longer; and though I alighted at\r\nyour gates, I determined not to enter within them; I lingered a few\r\nminutes to see the place, but was fully resolved to return to M\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\r\nwithout seeing its mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if my aunt and I had not been just returning from our morning\r\ndrive, I should have seen and heard no more of you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought it would be better for both that we should not meet,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied I, as calmly as I could, but not daring to speak above my\r\nbreath, from conscious inability to steady my voice, and not daring to\r\nlook in her face lest my firmness should forsake me altogether. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthought an interview would only disturb your peace and madden me. But I\r\nam glad, now, of this opportunity of seeing you once more and knowing\r\nthat you have not forgotten me, and of assuring you that I shall never\r\ncease to remember you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause. Mrs. Huntingdon moved away, and stood in\r\nthe recess of the window. Did she regard this as an intimation that\r\nmodesty alone prevented me from asking her hand? and was she\r\nconsidering how to repulse me with the smallest injury to my feelings?\r\nBefore I could speak to relieve her from such a perplexity, she broke\r\nthe silence herself by suddenly turning towards me and observing\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might have had such an opportunity before\xe2\x80\x94as far, I mean, as\r\nregards assuring me of your kindly recollections, and yourself of mine,\r\nif you had written to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would have done so, but I did not know your address, and did not\r\nlike to ask your brother, because I thought he would object to my\r\nwriting; but this would not have deterred me for a moment, if I could\r\nhave ventured to believe that you expected to hear from me, or even\r\nwasted a thought upon your unhappy friend; but your silence naturally\r\nled me to conclude myself forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you expect me to write to _you_, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Helen\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Huntingdon,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, blushing at the implied\r\nimputation, \xe2\x80\x9ccertainly not; but if you had sent me a message through\r\nyour brother, or even asked him about me now and then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did ask about you frequently. I was not going to do more,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nshe, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cso long as you continued to restrict yourself to a few\r\npolite inquiries about my health.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour brother never told me that you had mentioned my name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever ask him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; for I saw he did not wish to be questioned about you, or to afford\r\nthe slightest encouragement or assistance to my too obstinate\r\nattachment.\xe2\x80\x9d Helen did not reply. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd he was perfectly right,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nI. But she remained in silence, looking out upon the snowy lawn. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\r\nwill relieve her of my presence,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I; and immediately I rose and\r\nadvanced to take leave, with a most heroic resolution\xe2\x80\x94but pride was at\r\nthe bottom of it, or it could not have carried me through.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going already?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, taking the hand I offered, and not\r\nimmediately letting it go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I stay any longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait till Arthur comes, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnly too glad to obey, I stood and leant against the opposite side of\r\nthe window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou told me you were not changed,\xe2\x80\x9d said my companion: \xe2\x80\x9cyou _are_\xe2\x80\x94very\r\nmuch so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mrs. Huntingdon, I only ought to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to maintain that you have the same regard for me that you\r\nhad when last we met?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have; but it would be wrong to talk of it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was wrong to talk of it _then_, Gilbert; it would _not_ now\xe2\x80\x94unless\r\nto do so would be to violate the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was too much agitated to speak; but, without waiting for an answer,\r\nshe turned away her glistening eye and crimson cheek, and threw up the\r\nwindow and looked out, whether to calm her own, excited feelings, or to\r\nrelieve her embarrassment, or only to pluck that beautiful half-blown\r\nChristmas-rose that grew upon the little shrub without, just peeping\r\nfrom the snow that had hitherto, no doubt, defended it from the frost,\r\nand was now melting away in the sun. Pluck it, however, she did, and\r\nhaving gently dashed the glittering powder from its leaves, approached\r\nit to her lips and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis rose is not so fragrant as a summer flower, but it has stood\r\nthrough hardships none of _them_ could bear: the cold rain of winter\r\nhas sufficed to nourish it, and its faint sun to warm it; the bleak\r\nwinds have not blanched it, or broken its stem, and the keen frost has\r\nnot blighted it. Look, Gilbert, it is still fresh and blooming as a\r\nflower can be, with the cold snow even now on its petals.\xe2\x80\x94Will you have\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI held out my hand: I dared not speak lest my emotion should overmaster\r\nme. She laid the rose across my palm, but I scarcely closed my fingers\r\nupon it, so deeply was I absorbed in thinking what might be the meaning\r\nof her words, and what I ought to do or say upon the occasion; whether\r\nto give way to my feelings or restrain them still. Misconstruing this\r\nhesitation into indifference\xe2\x80\x94or reluctance even\xe2\x80\x94to accept her gift,\r\nHelen suddenly snatched it from my hand, threw it out on to the snow,\r\nshut down the window with an emphasis, and withdrew to the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen, what means this?\xe2\x80\x9d I cried, electrified at this startling change\r\nin her demeanour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did not understand my gift,\xe2\x80\x9d said she\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cor, what is worse, you\r\ndespised it. I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry I gave it you; but since I did make such a\r\nmistake, the only remedy I could think of was to take it away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou misunderstood me cruelly,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied, and in a minute I had opened\r\nthe window again, leaped out, picked up the flower, brought it in, and\r\npresented it to her, imploring her to give it me again, and I would\r\nkeep it for ever for her sake, and prize it more highly than anything\r\nin the world I possessed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will this content you?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as she took it in her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt shall,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, then; take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI pressed it earnestly to my lips, and put it in my bosom, Mrs.\r\nHuntingdon looking on with a half-sarcastic smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will if\xe2\x80\x94if I must.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou _are_ changed,\xe2\x80\x9d persisted she\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou are grown either very proud or\r\nvery indifferent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am neither, Helen\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Huntingdon. If you could see my heart\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou _must_ be one,\xe2\x80\x94if not both. And why Mrs. Huntingdon?\xe2\x80\x94why not\r\nHelen, as before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen, then\xe2\x80\x94dear Helen!\xe2\x80\x9d I murmured. I was in an agony of mingled\r\nlove, hope, delight, uncertainty, and suspense.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe rose I gave you was an emblem of my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cwould you\r\ntake it away and leave me here alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you give me your hand too, if I asked it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I not said enough?\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, with a most enchanting smile. I\r\nsnatched her hand, and would have fervently kissed it, but suddenly\r\nchecked myself, and said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut have you considered the consequences?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHardly, I think, or I should not have offered myself to one too proud\r\nto take me, or too indifferent to make his affection outweigh my\r\nworldly goods.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStupid blockhead that I was!\xe2\x80\x94I trembled to clasp her in my arms, but\r\ndared not believe in so much joy, and yet restrained myself to say,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if you _should_ repent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be your fault,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied: \xe2\x80\x9cI never shall, unless you\r\nbitterly disappoint me. If you have not sufficient confidence in my\r\naffection to believe this, let me alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy darling angel\xe2\x80\x94my _own Helen_,\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, now passionately kissing\r\nthe hand I still retained, and throwing my left arm around her, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nnever shall repent, if it depend on me alone. But have you thought of\r\nyour aunt?\xe2\x80\x9d I trembled for the answer, and clasped her closer to my\r\nheart in the instinctive dread of losing my new-found treasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy aunt must not know of it yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cShe would think it a\r\nrash, wild step, because she could not imagine how well I know you; but\r\nshe must know you herself, and learn to like you. You must leave us\r\nnow, after lunch, and come again in spring, and make a longer stay, and\r\ncultivate her acquaintance, and I know you will like each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then you will be mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, printing a kiss upon her lips, and\r\nanother, and another; for I was as daring and impetuous now as I had\r\nbeen backward and constrained before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94in another year,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she, gently disengaging herself from my\r\nembrace, but still fondly clasping my hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother year! Oh, Helen, I could not wait so long!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is your fidelity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean I could not endure the misery of so long a separation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would not be a separation: we will write every day: my spirit shall\r\nbe always with you, and sometimes you shall see me with your bodily\r\neye. I will not be such a hypocrite as to pretend that I desire to wait\r\nso long myself, but as my marriage is to please myself, alone, I ought\r\nto consult my friends about the time of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour friends will disapprove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey will not greatly disapprove, dear Gilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, earnestly\r\nkissing my hand; \xe2\x80\x9cthey cannot, when they know you, or, if they could,\r\nthey would not be true friends\xe2\x80\x94I should not care for their\r\nestrangement. Now are you satisfied?\xe2\x80\x9d She looked up in my face with a\r\nsmile of ineffable tenderness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I be otherwise, with your love? And you _do_ love me, Helen?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nI, not doubting the fact, but wishing to hear it confirmed by her own\r\nacknowledgment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you loved as _I_ do,\xe2\x80\x9d she earnestly replied, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would not have so\r\nnearly lost me\xe2\x80\x94these scruples of false delicacy and pride would never\r\nthus have troubled you\xe2\x80\x94you would have seen that the greatest worldly\r\ndistinctions and discrepancies of rank, birth, and fortune are as dust\r\nin the balance compared with the unity of accordant thoughts and\r\nfeelings, and truly loving, sympathising hearts and souls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this is too much happiness,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, embracing her again; \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nnot deserved it, Helen\xe2\x80\x94I dare not believe in such felicity: and the\r\nlonger I have to wait, the greater will be my dread that something will\r\nintervene to snatch you from me\xe2\x80\x94and think, a thousand things may happen\r\nin a year!\xe2\x80\x94I shall be in one long fever of restless terror and\r\nimpatience all the time. And besides, winter is such a dreary season.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought so too,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she gravely: \xe2\x80\x9cI would not be married in\r\nwinter\xe2\x80\x94in December, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, with a shudder\xe2\x80\x94for in that\r\nmonth had occurred both the ill-starred marriage that had bound her to\r\nher former husband, and the terrible death that released her\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand\r\ntherefore I said another year, in spring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Next_ spring?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no\xe2\x80\x94next autumn, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSummer, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the close of summer. There now! be satisfied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile she was speaking Arthur re-entered the room\xe2\x80\x94good boy for keeping\r\nout so long.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find the book in either of the places you told me to\r\nlook for it\xe2\x80\x9d (there was a conscious something in mamma\xe2\x80\x99s smile that\r\nseemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, dear, I knew you could not\xe2\x80\x9d), \xe2\x80\x9cbut Rachel got it\r\nfor me at last. Look, Mr. Markham, a natural history, with all kinds of\r\nbirds and beasts in it, and the reading as nice as the pictures!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn great good humour I sat down to examine the book, and drew the\r\nlittle fellow between my knees. Had he come a minute before I should\r\nhave received him less graciously, but now I affectionately stroked his\r\ncurling locks, and even kissed his ivory forehead: he was my own\r\nHelen\xe2\x80\x99s son, and therefore mine; and as such I have ever since regarded\r\nhim. That pretty child is now a fine young man: he has realised his\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s brightest expectations, and is at present residing in\r\nGrassdale Manor with his young wife\xe2\x80\x94the merry little Helen Hattersley\r\nof yore.\r\n\r\nI had not looked through half the book before Mrs. Maxwell appeared to\r\ninvite me into the other room to lunch. That lady\xe2\x80\x99s cool, distant\r\nmanners rather chilled me at first; but I did my best to propitiate\r\nher, and not entirely without success, I think, even in that first\r\nshort visit; for when I talked cheerfully to her, she gradually became\r\nmore kind and cordial, and when I departed she bade me a gracious\r\nadieu, hoping ere long to have the pleasure of seeing me again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you must not go till you have seen the conservatory, my aunt\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwinter garden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Helen, as I advanced to take leave of her, with as\r\nmuch philosophy and self-command as I could summon to my aid.\r\n\r\nI gladly availed myself of such a respite, and followed her into a\r\nlarge and beautiful conservatory, plentifully furnished with flowers,\r\nconsidering the season\xe2\x80\x94but, of course, I had little attention to spare\r\nfor _them_. It was not, however, for any tender colloquy that my\r\ncompanion had brought me there:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy aunt is particularly fond of flowers,\xe2\x80\x9d she observed, \xe2\x80\x9cand she is\r\nfond of Staningley too: I brought you here to offer a petition in her\r\nbehalf, that this may be her home as long as she lives, and\xe2\x80\x94if it be\r\nnot our home likewise\xe2\x80\x94that I may often see her and be with her; for I\r\nfear she will be sorry to lose me; and though she leads a retired and\r\ncontemplative life, she is apt to get low-spirited if left too much\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means, dearest Helen!\xe2\x80\x94do what you will with your own. I should\r\nnot dream of wishing your aunt to leave the place under any\r\ncircumstances; and we will live either here or elsewhere as you and she\r\nmay determine, and you shall see her as often as you like. I know she\r\nmust be pained to part with you, and I am willing to make any\r\nreparation in my power. I love her for your sake, and her happiness\r\nshall be as dear to me as that of my own mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, darling! you shall have a kiss for that. Good-by. There\r\nnow\xe2\x80\x94there, Gilbert\xe2\x80\x94let me go\xe2\x80\x94here\xe2\x80\x99s Arthur; don\xe2\x80\x99t astonish his\r\ninfantile brain with your madness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n* * * * *\r\n\r\n\r\nBut it is time to bring my narrative to a close. Any one but you would\r\nsay I had made it too long already. But for _your_ satisfaction I will\r\nadd a few words more; because I know you will have a fellow-feeling for\r\nthe old lady, and will wish to know the last of her history. I did come\r\nagain in spring, and, agreeably to Helen\xe2\x80\x99s injunctions, did my best to\r\ncultivate her acquaintance. She received me very kindly, having been,\r\ndoubtless, already prepared to think highly of my character by her\r\nniece\xe2\x80\x99s too favourable report. I turned my best side out, of course,\r\nand we got along marvellously well together. When my ambitious\r\nintentions were made known to her, she took it more sensibly than I had\r\nventured to hope. Her only remark on the subject, in my hearing, was\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, Mr. Markham, you are going to rob me of my niece, I\r\nunderstand. Well! I hope God will prosper your union, and make my dear\r\ngirl happy at last. Could she have been contented to remain single, I\r\nown I should have been better satisfied; but if she must marry again, I\r\nknow of no one, now living and of a suitable age, to whom I would more\r\nwillingly resign her than yourself, or who would be more likely to\r\nappreciate her worth and make, her truly happy, as far as I can tell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOf course I was delighted with the compliment, and hoped to show her\r\nthat she was not mistaken in her favourable judgment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have, however, one request to offer,\xe2\x80\x9d continued she. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems I am\r\nstill to look on Staningley as my home: I wish you to make it yours\r\nlikewise, for Helen is attached to the place and to me\xe2\x80\x94as I am to her.\r\nThere are painful associations connected with Grassdale, which she\r\ncannot easily overcome; and I shall not molest you with my company or\r\ninterference here: I am a very quiet person, and shall keep my own\r\napartments, and attend to my own concerns, and only see you now and\r\nthen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOf course I most readily consented to this; and we lived in the\r\ngreatest harmony with our dear aunt until the day of her death, which\r\nmelancholy event took place a few years after\xe2\x80\x94melancholy, not to\r\nherself (for it came quietly upon her, and she was glad to reach her\r\njourney\xe2\x80\x99s end), but only to the few loving friends and grateful\r\ndependents she left behind.\r\n\r\nTo return, however, to my own affairs: I was married in summer, on a\r\nglorious August morning. It took the whole eight months, and all\r\nHelen\xe2\x80\x99s kindness and goodness to boot, to overcome my mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprejudices against my bride-elect, and to reconcile her to the idea of\r\nmy leaving Linden Grange and living so far away. Yet she was gratified\r\nat her son\xe2\x80\x99s good fortune after all, and proudly attributed it all to\r\nhis own superior merits and endowments. I bequeathed the farm to\r\nFergus, with better hopes of its prosperity than I should have had a\r\nyear ago under similar circumstances; for he had lately fallen in love\r\nwith the Vicar of L\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99s eldest daughter\xe2\x80\x94a lady whose superiority had\r\nroused his latent virtues, and stimulated him to the most surprising\r\nexertions, not only to gain her affection and esteem, and to obtain a\r\nfortune sufficient to aspire to her hand, but to render himself worthy\r\nof her, in his own eyes, as well as in those of her parents; and in the\r\nend he was successful, as you already know. As for myself, I need not\r\ntell you how happily my Helen and I have lived together, and how\r\nblessed we still are in each other\xe2\x80\x99s society, and in the promising\r\nyoung scions that are growing up about us. We are just now looking\r\nforward to the advent of you and Rose, for the time of your annual\r\nvisit draws nigh, when you must leave your dusty, smoky, noisy,\r\ntoiling, striving city for a season of invigorating relaxation and\r\nsocial retirement with us.\r\n\r\nTill then, farewell,\r\nGILBERT MARKHAM.\r\n\r\n\r\n_Staningley_, _June_ 10_th_, 1847.\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\nPrinted by SPOTTISWOODE, BALLENTYNE & CO. LTD.\r\nColchester, London & Eton, England.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFootnotes:\r\n\r\n [1] Introduction to _Wuthering Heights_, p. xl. \xe2\x80\x9cStill, as I mused the\r\n naked room,\xe2\x80\x9d &c.\r\n\r\n [2] This Preface is now printed here for the first time in a collected\r\n edition of the works of the Bront\xc3\xab sisters.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n*** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK THE TENANT OF WILDFELL HALL ***\r\n\r\n***** This file should be named 969-0.txt or 969-0.zip *****\r\nThis and all associated files of various formats will be found in:\r\n    https://www.gutenberg.org/9/6/969/\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the\r\nUnited States without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
